When you are deemed too "high risk" for pain or ADHD treatment, your care is reminiscent of the abusive relationships that can lead to PTSD- you have no voice, no control over your life/body, they abuse you in private so nobody believes you & try to convince you it never happened

She was MAD that I called her a Dr, bc she was a nurse. I said medical misogyny is well-documented among doctors, & she spat out "I'm a nurse, not a doctor. If you're going to attack me at least get it right!" Like sorry I gave you a more impressive credential you don't deserve?

remembering the time a psych insisted she couldn't be sexist in the mental health care she provided bc she was a woman, but then she wouldn't talk about my ADHD with me & instead talked extensively about me to my white, male partner. 3 different times. Ah yes- no sexism here boys
So uhhh still no under 5 vaccine, right? Cool. Cool cool cool. https://t.co/aqPYuCigrG

I dunno, maybe I'm broken in some fundamental way, but it seems absurd to blacklist trauma survivors from healthcare ostensibly to protect them from substance use disorder. Perhaps so many PTSDers have SUD bc trauma care is laughable & they get blacklisted instead of treated?

So someone w trauma & ADHD discloses trauma when asked, takes meds, doesn't get better, has additional stresses & strains of ADHD, realizes they are blacklisted from ADHD care bc of the trauma nobody addressed, quits bc it's not helping, maybe seeks illicit drugs that do help

ADHD & autistic women are targeted. We're more likely to be abused or sexually assaulted, more likely to live in poverty, we have increased rates of eating disorders, car crashes, & suicide attempts. Our trauma is part of surviving as a ND person in a NT world. It's inseparable.

I imagine many women w PTSD are like me- they were honest, said they had things to work through, didn't get any help for PTSD, took the antidepressants & so on but nothing helped, & eventually they stopped trying. They worked through it on their own, bc nobody else gave a shit

Nobody should have to choose between healthcare for trauma & healthcare for chronic pain or ADHD. Nobody should have to choose one hurt to heal while the others spiral out of control. Banning trauma survivors from pain or ADHD meds (or anything really) does not heal trauma

If I could go back in time I'd tell myself not to disclose anything that someone else did: not my father's alcohol use disorder, or abuse or sexual assault. I'd tell myself that ER is a TV show, doctors don't give a shit, & being an open book (like I usually am) will only hurt me

I trusted healthcare. From an early age I trusted that doing the wise, healthy thing, being open & seeking help, would be the best way to go. I'm a real sucker for the just-world fallacy. But in reality, trusting healthcare was more like volunteering myself to be barred from it.

CW: child sexual assault
.

I have an boomer relative who survived more severe CSA than me. But since she never dealt w it, never told her healthcare providers, she is considered low risk enough to get monthly opioids for pain. I did the "right" thing & got blacklisted for it

I think this unwritten "PTSD means no meds" rule also particularly targets younger women & girls. We've been bombarded w messages about speaking out against gendered violence, encouraged to be open & seek care, but just going to the hospital after abuse or rape may blacklist us

To be fair I don't know for certain that the NarxCare algorithm only punishes women for surviving sexual assault, we don't get to know how it works. But I do know that the algorithm is based on opioid risk assessment tools like the ORT (picture), which do exclusively punish women https://t.co/JlIZ0Da4u7

beyond being denied necessary meds, you likely won't be able to get a Dr to listen to *any* health concern you have. You won't get care for all this ~dangerous~ trauma, but you will be considered hysterical & untrustworthy. Women who disclose trauma are filtered out of healthcare

can't stress this enough: it isn't safe to disclose history of abuse or sexual assault (esp in childhood) if you are a woman. Not to any Dr or therapist. Not to mental or physical healthcare. If you do, you may someday need pain management or ADHD meds & be deemed too "high risk"

It should be obvious that denying someone healthcare bc they have been victimized is massively unethical, but when it comes to the War on Drugs the priority will always be reducing access to drugs for the poor & marginalized, even (or especially) at the expense of their health

Casual reminder that denying a patient appropriate healthcare because they have trauma is victim-blaming bullshit which only furthers the harm done to them. Restricting pain & ADHD medication for someone on the basis that *someone else* hurt them is despicable & discriminatory

The worst thing is when you say something you know you quoted from somewhere else, the person you're talking to gets the reference, and they ask you about it or try to talk about it but you don't remember where you got it because you've been using it for years or decades now
Oh god I started thinking about the booming skeleton voice in Lost Skeleton and now the line "That is how st*pid you are!" keeps playing on loop in my head

To be clear this is echolalia- just repeating things I've heard in my head (or out loud) over & over & over, but I'm imagining/remembering the booming voice, it's not an auditory hallucination where I think I'm literally hearing the booming voice
I think it might be Lost Skeleton of Cadavera, just based on the booming voice (<- by the way one of the funniest and most quotable movies I've seen in the last decade)

Autistic movie talk is wild bc so so much of my speech is references and quotes, and I've got such a backlog of them that sometimes I can't remember where they came from? Like right now I have a booming voice in my head like "IT IS A MYSTERY" but I can't remember what that's from

How do I teach her to regulate her emotions if I can't regulate my own? How do I teach her patience & persistence when I have none? How do I give her attention when I don't control where my attention goes? Why don't I deserve help? Is another generation going to suffer for it?

I'm used to pain for myself. That's just life at this point: nothing goes right. I didn't get diagnosed ADHD despite so much evidence of it, I accidentally dropped out of high school, I finally had my dream baby & a pandemic hit. But thinking abt her suffering bc of me breaks me

I looked at my beautiful kid and when she smiles she looks exactly like me. And she's eager, she's bright, she's "quirky" (ADHD/A) like I am. I'm so afraid I'm going to fail her the same way I was failed bc I can't get ADHD treatment, & my kid is going to suffer the way I have

For a long time I thought my "mood swings" just came out of nowhere, subject to the whims of bipolar disorder. I was unable to anticipate or mitigate it. But it's not bipolar, it's ADHD. It doesn't just happen, it's almost always a response- even just to my own sad/angry thoughts

If I tell a psych about the years-long rumination it takes to process an event that really upset me & I feel this festering anger & howling bitterness, they will see it as dangerous instead of what my brain has to do to understand the event & stop emotionally hemorrhaging over it

Got distracted trying to figure out what tree this is (white winter buds, kinda smells like bacon when cut, apple?) but I'm still deeeeeep into this pit of emotional dysregulation & devastation, which is very silly like I'm crying over my lost future while looking up tree buds https://t.co/JHJftBW89j

It feels like I was robbed. It feels like something was taken from me & I can never get it back- my body, my mind, my security, ability to trust & believe myself, ability to care for myself & for the ppl I love- all bc doctors wrongly believed girls can't be ADHD or autistic

That hole is deep. When I fall its sudden & feels like I'll never get out. It only lasts a few hours, maybe a day, but it is devastating. Its like #autism pipes in w a factual recapping of negative events, which turns into rumination, which makes #ADHD hit the BIG FEELINGS button

I had an amazing day. My kid & I went for a walk, went to the park, had 3 hrs of fun, & then on the walk home I had this stab of hurt bc I'm not going to be able to give my kid a sibling bc I can't get treated for #ADHD, which sent me spiraling abt what I lost due to misdiagnosis

I've accidentally downvoted people four times this morning because the downvote button is now where the like button used to be, so yay. I love anxiety, uncertainty, and accidentally punishing my friends on my social media, thanks @Twitter

I wonder if people who are both autistic & ADHD are more likely to mask, because rejection sensitive dysphoria makes us so so sensitive to rejection or the perception of rejection that we contort ourselves horribly trying to emulate social norms we don't really understand

my RSD gets unbearable, I'm frustrated, I'm afraid I'm going to feel these symptoms forever & never feel better. I make a few under my breath comments (nothing wild but any hint of frustration is seen as a red flag for "drug-seeking"). I get lectured & go into semi-shutdown

when the doctor inevitably blows me off & hands me a prescription for antidepressants/NSAIDs my emotional dysregulation takes off, I relive every bad medical experience, I feel desperate bc all I want is to feel better why the fuck is this so hard, & communication gets 10x harder

Drs offices are one of the few places I experience severe anxiety, my medical PTSD & RSD go haywire, I'm physically uncomfortable, so despite my interest I just fumble all my words, can't remember words/details, say whatever I can manage to get out, & can't advocate for myself

It's frustrating to not be able to communicate effectively when I choose to. It's frustrating that I have to hit some magical threshold of interest and/or my symptoms have to be sufficiently managed in order for me to remember words & put them in order to make a compelling point

Ugh I'm very frustrated because my hyperverbal brain desperately wants to rant about something, anything, but it's difficult to think clearly and words just aren't doing very well making it from my brain to my fingers. When it clicks I write pretty well, but when it doesn't...

Ooh, or the Jack of all Trades vs Specialist conflict: where ADHD is like a scavenger hunt to see what random thing will make the dopamine printer go brrrr so you're constantly moving from interest to interest, but autism grabs some of those things to become a long-term fixation

Another one is the way that ADHD makes me feel like I have to constantly be entertaining people so they don't reject me (unsurprisingly I've had a lot of social rejection) but I have trouble telling if someone is being sarcastic or is annoyed & I end up being Too Much for people

So I'll get under my weighted blanket to mitigate the Bad Body Feels, feel better for a few minutes, get restless & feel like I need to move, sit up and start rocking, feel better for a few minutes, get back under the weighted blanket, and so on and so on

There are so many weird contradictions for people who are #ADHD & #autistic, but the one that always bewilders me is being simultaneously understimulated and overstimulated. Like please please just pick a way to fuck me up and stick with it

Ok this kid has spent the last ten minutes talking to me about dump trucks but not looking at me so I'm pretty sure he's one of us... oh god oh god the moms are fighting. Not fistfighting but like arguing real loud. What the fuck do I do now?
The other kids keep talking to me and the moms are looking at me weird and I'm like "I'm just standing here I don't know why this is happening either"

Okay I take everything else back, the worst part of being ADHD/autistic is taking your kid to the park & there are moms there and you just stand there awkwardly while the kids talk to you. I don't know how to mom in front of other moms. What are mom?

Woo, lookin forward to my birthday this year. Gonna be another awesome day of isolation & exhaustion!

The best part of my birthday now is remembering that a few days before it my state went on lockdown & I was plunged into endless isolation w a kid who was, at the time, eight weeks old, & also I lost all the precious introducing baby to extended family moments & now they hate me
RT @Mollyissilly: Covid is much like Wu-Tang in the sense that it’s forever.

The "opioid crisis" & draconian restriction of opioids & stimulants over the last 10 yrs set the US up for a uniquely terrible Covid response. We've spent a decade telling patients that doctors are drug dealers & pushing patients out of care. Our chickens have come home to roost.

Leaving so many patients on their own for years or decades, leaving them to seek out their own solutions online or from a dealer because no doctor will even deign to test them, that's a great recipe for pandemic disaster- you wanted to squeeze us out of healthcare? You got it.

Someone w chronic pain may spend ten years trying to get healthcare to manage their pain, to do things the right way, but eventually they may just give up & use cannabis, kratom, or illicit opioids. An ADHDer might beg for help, be called a "drug-seeker," & seek out alternatives

We hear a lot of scolding about getting health information & treatment outside of the medical establishment, but there's very little understanding of *why* a patient might choose (or feel forced) to go outside the system for help, & how that impacts longterm healthcare attitudes

I'm not familiar w anthelmintics, but thats an important point. I use Kratom for chronic pain & the discomfort of hyperactivity. FDA has tried to ban it for years & CDC calls it "harmful." I'm pro-vax, but I can see how other kratom users might instinctively distrust CDC on Covid https://t.co/lndBAhCJRY

The image of wellness culture is white, wealthy women (and they certainly have the money to pursue extravagant stuff) but wellness culture is aspirational. Poor & marginalized people who have found nothing but suspicion & derision in healthcare take refuge in Wellness. I did.

But anyways, which would you rather do- spend potentially thousands of dollars over several years so doctors can tell you you're only in pain because you keep thinking about/anticipating pain (true story), or spend $100 on equally useless essential oils that at least smell nice?

Kinda wish I had a window to see into alternate universes a la Fringe, so I could see how the pandemic went for places that *didn't* respond to a rise in OD deaths w a propaganda campaign about "innocent" (aka white) patients being duped into ~addiction~ by unscrupulous doctors

Also as an aside- it's probably not great for vaccine uptake that the anti-opioid movement spent the last 10+ years calling doctors "drug dealers," while media uses images of spoons + needles to represent prescription drugs & claims that just being near fentanyl can kill you

I'm seeing a lot more women/BIPoC/poor people who have quit seeking healthcare altogether bc they have no hope of having their health concerns taken seriously. I'm one of them. There is no healthcare for the poor & marginalized, & wellness culture is there to pick up the pieces

Drs have spent a lot of time saying "the science! THE SCIENCE!" during Covid (fair), but lemme tell you as a poor woman w ADHD & autism (who had to diagnose myself before getting officially dxed)- patients who discuss the science in their Dr's offices are often punished for it

I mean look at who tends to buy into alternative healthcare trends, essential oils, wellness bullshit- people who can't get healthcare due to gender, race, or class bias, people who seek healthcare & get nothing but weight-shaming, "learn to live with it," & wellness slogans

It's not a coincidence the wellness industry targets & is overwhelmingly bought into by women. Not only are we subjected to white, western beauty standards to an absurd degree, but we also can't get healthcare the way men can. Weight is not a HC barrier for my white, male partner

When women are told they don't need pain management, given some antidepressants/NSAIDs & told to "try mindfulness" they have been primed to try any pseudoscientific or even outright harmful "treatment" which alleges to help them manage the pain their doctor will not acknowledge

Again no offense to this doctor, I don't know them, I follow a few great doctors & they very well could be one too. But when patients are routinely blown off based on metrics that are widely acknowledged to be unscientific, those patients are being primed to accept pseudoscience

Wellness culture has blurred the lines between bullshit and healthcare, but the healthcare industry has too, and continues to promote shady pseudoscience to avoid testing or treating us ~lesser~ patients. Wellness culture has been a boon for medical misogyny, racism, & classism

Or we can talk about "mindfulness" and the proliferation of CBT courses for things that can't be fixed or treated via CBT (chronic pain, ADHD, autism). When I sought healthcare for back & pelvic pain my doctor simply said "try mindfulness." Turns out it was endometriosis. Oopsie.

One doctor who did bring up my weight (I was at my heaviest after 2 years of antidepressants that did not help me) was furious when I dared to suggest that BMI wasn't sound science, weight is largely determined by genetics, & my weight gain was caused by medication she prescribed

Funny story- I've been "overweight" most of my life, according to my BMI I've often been considered "obese," but I'm tall, carry weight differently, & doctors barely ever bring up my weight. My shorter friends with "better" BMIs hear about their weight at every appointment

I mean just ask any woman who has been denied testing for serious health concerns because "you just need to drop some weight." BMI is at best seriously flawed, at worst racist, sexist pseudoscience, but it's used to deny healthcare to women every day

Decent thread. No offense to this doctor, I don't know them, but it is kinda funny to me that doctors consider themselves separate from & better than wellness culture when so much of healthcare for anyone who isn't white, wealthy, & thin is virtually indistinguishable from it https://t.co/ZPusTPIJXI

v cool that the several times I brought up constantly losing or accidentally ruining important things, doctors said that was depression. Everything is depression. Cancer? Depression. Hit by a car? Depression. Climate change? Depression. The heat death of the universe? Depression.

Oh also I for sure lost my social security card too, probably ten years ago now. I put all my kid's documents in a folder in one particular drawer the moment I get them, and I check that drawer like three times a month bc I'm so afraid I'm going to lose them

No idea where my wallet is, haven't seen it in like 2-3 months. It has to be here somewhere, bc I don't really leave the house, but my ID and vax card are in there. One time I legit lost my birth certificate for 7 years, then found it in a random box. Yum yum, tastes like ADHD

It's cool how a history of sexual assault is part of why I can't access ADHD meds, but my untreated ADHD is a big part of why I didn't understand what was happening bc poor processing speed, couldn't say no bc RSD/couldn't stand up for myself. I was vulnerable bc I was untreated

@bitefullamight @Katyavixen So hypothetically if you were abused as a kid and told any healthcare provider about it (or if there was a court case associated with it) it could prevent you from getting ADHD medication decades later, prevent you from getting adequate pain mgmt late in life or if you get cancer

@bitefullamight @Katyavixen Its hard to say for sure, but iirc every state now requires that Drs check their respective Prescription Drug Monitoring Program before prescribing. Those programs are linked to NarxCare, which mines your criminal justice/EMS/EHR data for "red flags" to ostensibly predict risk

its especially infuriating to see the same media that breathlessly reports the most salacious aspects of the so-called "opioid crisis" & the architects of medical drug prohibition pretend that these built-to-fail policies have already succeeded, or will do so any minute now
And it's easy to continually farm the poor/marginalized for more profit & funding because nobody cares about them anyways- they're just losers or "addicts" or otherwise unworthy ~for some reason~

Their profits & funding are driven by criminalization, privatization, medical & non-medical drug prohibition, for-profit prisons, hospitals, unregulated rehab facilities. That money is squeezed out of the abject misery, unfulfilled promise & human fragility of the most vulnerable

Its absurd & cruel to me bc I want poor/marginalized patients to receive the quality care their white, wealthy & male peers get. But it makes perfect sense if you wanna maintain the status quo- profits for the prison, healthcare, & rehab industries + massive ⬆️ to police funding

The autistic in me needs to never stop talking abt it bc maybe if I keep talking abt it other people will see how horrifying, cruel & absurd this "Minority Report but make it healthcare" thing is. But we've long known how racist the algorithm for sentencing is & it's still in use

I just cannot let go of my anger and despair over the seemingly benign NarxCare predictive risk algorithm, which sorts patients into "worthy" and "not worthy" based on decontextualized data points associated with BIPoC, women, & poor people & damn near officially blacklists them

If patients are required to have spotless personal histories without a speck of trauma or any other "red flags" in order to receive effective treatment, the only people who will be able to get treated are wealthy white men (and their wives)- the people who need help the least.

We shouldn't have a healthcare system where AFAB people in their 30s & 40s are begging AFAB people in their teens & 20s to never, ever mention abuse or sexual assault in front of a doctor. Don't mention a family history of substance use either- you'll be guilty by association

AFAB patients talk abt the fact that their (often male) abusers can easily receive healthcare, are believed & treated w respect, receive medication, while their victim is tossed aside like garbage, still being harmed by their abuser as they continue to spiral without needed care

For a disturbingly large number of women, disclosing that you have been abused or sexually assaulted effectively ends your ability to receive healthcare. Not just opioids or stimulants- doctors won't even do diagnostic testing bc your trauma makes you an unreliable narrator

also, if there's a significant increase of substance use disorder in traumatized people, perhaps it's bc... they can't get healthcare due to their "high risk" status? Maybe it's difficult to heal from trauma when you can't function due to ADHD/pain & Drs keep calling you a liar?

We're told these traumatized people are just ~so~ likely to misuse prescription drugs (eh, it's modest) & must be protected from themselves, but the algorthim deciding our care is essentially branding poor/marginalized people as "damaged goods" & filtering them out of healthcare

People who have been traumatized- who have survived abuse, sexual assault, a racist criminal justice system, poverty, transphobia, etc- are considered too "high risk" for pain or ADHD care, which retraumatizes survivors, punishes the poor/marginalized, & alienates them from care

Oh good, the pain is winding its way up my neck, grabbing at the base of my skull, making it hurt to hold my head up. It's 4am and I can't sleep no matter how hard I try. I did get to watch Tony Shaloub dramatically flourish a cape on Mrs. Maisel, so that's something I guess

Like if I had ever been not-poor enough to live in a house that isn't freezing all winter I would've saved hundreds of hours where all I could do was lie down, cry, wish I could saw my arm off. Less pain would've left me more energy to manage life, ADHD, autism, being a person
Anytime someone says ADHD is their superpower I just hear "I have money"

And it would probably be easier to survive it if my fucking arm from shoulder to fingers didn't throb, lock up, go partially numb, every time my shoulder gets *slightly* too cold. Doctors said the pain is "anxiety." That's some goddamn temperature-sensitive anxiety but ok

Everything is hard & bleak. I don't know how to survive it anymore. I don't know if I've actually survived it so far, more like I stumbled & groped my way towards another day. The cool thing about ADHD is that everything is so much harder, *and* you're less emotionally resilient

Anxiety/depression are used as catch-alls, nobody invests time in girls bc they're considered drama queens, unreliable narrators, not competent enough to contribute to their care. They end up alienated from care when they need it most https://t.co/gIPLf9ELIC

My focus is still on writing abt ADHD, so that's what I've been doing for hours- wandering back & forth in my dining room, writing threads while rambling to my kid so she doesn't get lonely, forgetting to eat, sit, drink, or pee (don't worry- my kid is an excellent self-advocate)

#ADHD loves to do that shit. Like as a kid I would get so frustrated when I tried to read & couldn't get into it (didn't have a wide selection of books), but when my mom stuck me in my room until I cleaned it? I'd devour anything- teen magazines, true crime, romance, etc

It's nice bc my mind is always spinning so fucking fast & sometimes I can't translate that into words, so I desperate try to convey something but have no success saying what I want to say. I get frustrated, sometimes I just shut down. The lure of clear writing is hard to resist

Today I desperately wanted to get my house clean because it is.... not. great. But then its like my brain said "hey the body & I don't want to do that bc it's boring, so instead I'll let you be able to sort your thoughts so you can write all those threads you've wanted to write"
@Leslie_ness I get it, I have a lot of those days myself. I'm glad you related to it, it's really affirming to see that others struggle with this stuff too

Goddamnit I'm supposed to be cleaning my house and I've just spent the last... oh my god, six hours (!!) writing about ADHD and autism, but my hyperverbal mentally hyperactive brain just will not stop & my hyperactive body hasn't sat down & stopped moving for like three hours now

Emotional devastation is imminent. Either my kid will be denied, dismissed, shuttled to a more convenient diagnosis, & I'll feel the pain of watching her suffer like I did. Or... she'll get help. I'll be overjoyed, but I'll be seeing what I could've been if someone had helped me

But she's poor and a girl, and our healthcare system assigns less value to her success, comfort, safety, her ability to just live a life. I worry I've been so thoroughly labeled a "drug-seeker" for trying to get help that it will contaminate my kid's chances at help too

I don't like to think about that, because I have a toddler daughter who is almost certainly ADHD &/or autistic like her parents. I have to believe that early diagnosis & treatment can change the lives of young ADHDers. I don't want my daughter to be another poor girl left behind

One thing I've struggled to accept is that even official diagnosis & treatment likely wouldn't have led to adequate treatment, or could've even been more harmful to me. My poor, AFAB, & BIPoC friends dxed as kids didn't have an easier time- they were still poor & marginalized

@brad_lacey My partner is ADHD too, & we often talk about how we feel stuck mentally/emotionally/materially as our kid selves. I still feel 14, I get overwhelmed by boring adult shit almost instantly. We're learning as adults the kind of ADHD survival skills we should've been taught as kids

@brad_lacey Oof, I'm sorry. As a kid I constantly heard that I was so bright, so creative, that I was going to go to college & become something incredible. But around 6th grade I started sliding downhill bc I couldn't remember assignments or listen in class, & everyone just wrote me off

The fun thing about being dxed #ADHD/ #autistic well into adulthood is you end up being tortured by these like Sliding Doors daydreams abt the life you could've had if you had been diagnosed & treated as a kid. But the factors that left you undxed would've left you untxed too

I want to believe it was ignorance. That they weren't looking for ADHD & autism because of my gender & thus missed these incredibly obvious signs of ADHD/A. If the problem is ignorance, that can be addressed. I suspect the answer back then was convenience. Now its DEA compulsion

I have to wonder- did the psychs who guided me away from #ADHD do so out of ignorance, out of convenience, out of bias? Low income mental health providers tend to be young w little experience, & the older ones have usually already written all their patients off as "drug-seekers"

I kept asking for help as a 32 y/o who took all their antidepressants, mood stabilizers, antipsychotics, anticonvulsants- drugs they spent half my life claiming I needed- & didn't improve. At 32 I finally got my ADHD dx, but seeking treatment led to the worst medical trauma yet

I started asking for help at 5 or 6 yrs old, bc my legs "hurt" (I didn't know how else to describe the agony of trying to keep my hyperactive body still). I asked for help as a kid, as a teen who kept getting kicked out of class for talking & then having big RSD feelings about it

I told psychs that my body felt like an overwound guitar string, a kettle with the vent blocked- "anxiety." I said as a kid I'd cover my legs in icy hot & wrap them as tightly as I could in ace bandages bc it was the only way to stop the jerking & restless ache- "growing pains"

I told psychs when a big upset happens in my life- usually a social conflict- I spend 2 to 3 years ruminating on it nearly endlessly, w only brief respites thanks to daydreaming. That was called bipolar. I tried to describe overstimulation, but it was called PTSD hypervigilence

In retrospect it's astounding how often psychs skillfully guided me away from even considering #ADHD & #autism. I told them how I rock or sway constantly, they'd mumble about anxiety & move on quickly. Said I couldn't keep my house clean & they did the "its depression" dodge

I can't stop rambling, this thread has gone all over the place (per usual), so... fin?

In summary:
-abolish prisons & police
-legalization & safe drug supply now
-there is no justice for poor & marginalized ADHDers within racist, sexist, & classist systems/institutions

That's not a condemnation of ADHD/A twitter, I never would've figured out my ADHD/A without y'all. Nobody is coming to help poor/marginalized ppl- we need this info to advocate for ourselves. But we also need to examine systems that force many ADHD/Aers to use memes for diagnosis

I'm grateful for the community stripping ourselves bare to reach our fellow #ADHD-ers & #ActuallyAutistic folks, but even on the bird site it is an incomplete examination trending towards the white & wealthy. I don't see a lot of people who ended up like me (or even worse off)

There is no hope of justice or treatment for poor & marginalized #ADHD-ers without Black liberation, women's liberation, working class solidarity. There is no version of justice for ADHDers that coexists w mass incarceration, racist institutions, & controlling the bodies of women

I didn't understand my ADHD until I was able to manage it in an alternate way. I'm poor, devastated, in constant chaos, & I'm still one of the lucky ones- at least I know, at least I'm not left to buy black market Adderall laced w fentanyl, risking OD or prison for treatment

#ADHD & #autism have gained a bit of public understanding through the exhausting work of ppl sacrificing privacy in order to reach our ppl & educate NTs. But even this leads to a kind of survivorship bias- the ones who get treated & talk about it tend to be white & middle class

The reasons #ADHD women, poor ppl, BIPoC continue to go without care are bigger than individual practioner bias. Our prisons are stuffed full of untreated ADHDers. ADHD discourse must tackle drug policy, incarceration, the pipeline that shoots kids like us from school to prison

It's hard to define solutions for a problem so widespread & systemically enforced. Awareness is good- I'm so grateful I discovered my #ADHD in part through things like @ADHD_Alien- but we must go farther than social/career ADHD tolerance for people with white skin & white collars

As disgusting, incompetent, & discriminatory as individual mental health practitioners can be (sorry #psychtwitter but it's true), they operate within a system that sees poor ppl, Black ppl, women as inherently unworthy of care- backed by an algorithm confirming their prejudices

I'm no better or worse than any person who uses a drug- any drug, legal or not. Beyond the fact that the vast majority of drug users never develop a use disorder, preserving safer, legal drugs for the rich & white leaves no option but an illicit drug supply poisoned w fentanyl

So you know what: I am a drug-seeker. I am seeking the most effective treatment for a neurodevelopmental disability that has wreaked havoc on my life. I would like the drugs that help my brain create chemicals it is not capable of creating on its own so I can reclaim my life

When poor & marginalized groups beg for healthcare, beg to be treated as human beings, we are written off by media, "experts" who made bank testifying in state/federal opioid trials, politicians- we are not allowed to be anything but "drug-seekers."

The system we have would rather see women dependent on families or partners (at tremendous risk for abuse), see women in prison, see women develop eating disorders or substance use disorder, than deign to give them the scary, scary ~drugs~ for ADHD. Why that's a boy disorder!

And this is just the #ADHD side, for #autistic people & #ADHDautism, things are equally bad (or substanially worse). The system we have would rather see Black, Indigenous, & Latinx ADHD/A folks dead or in prison than deign to give them the drugs reserved for the white & wealthy

If we look at incarcerated women we also find around 40% of them met #ADHD criteria in childhood, and continue to meet that criteria as adults. ADHD is increasingly being linked to criminality, but god forbid we interrogate why so many ADHDers go untreated
https://t.co/U9sohTaCpq https://t.co/cLohLEUJPB

One study of a Colorado prison found that 40% of people who were incarcerated with longterm sentences were #ADHD. Only 2 out of 30 were dxed in childhood. Black people in particular don't get ADHD dx & tx- they end up in legal slavery via incarceration https://t.co/ndGdJBqZUt. https://t.co/9pVKG4fTYz

Medical drug prohibition has led to safe, legal drugs for the white & wealthy, and desperation, suffering, medical trauma, illicit substance use (and possibly illicit fentanyl poisoning), OD death, and/or prison for the rest of us. Some are deemed worthy of help, and some are not

My misdx led to self-hatred over things I didn't know were symptoms, MH drugs which often made me feel worse (and possibly caused seizures?), no ability to understand myself, healthcare trauma, PTSD, a decade on SSDI, & poverty. But hey at least I didn't get the bad drugs, right?

Many of us have simply quit seeking healthcare at all, because even if something is seriously wrong we know nobody will believe us anyways. When the ER confirmed my ankle was broken, I said "thank god," bc I was so happy the pain could be proven (still poorly managed tho)

When you've been traumatized by healthcare discrimination, you learn to stop trusting yourself, stop believing yourself, & most importantly to stop advocating for yourself lest you be labeled a "drug-seeker." You learn to shut up & be grateful someone is willing to see you at all

I don't often experience anxiety in my day to day life (probably in part bc I don't leave the house much anymore), but I have full blown panic attacks when I take my daughter to her pediatrician. I have medical PTSD. Doctor's offices are an unsafe, often hostile place for me

BIPoC, women, poor people have every right to be furious at a system which reserves the ADHD label & most effective ADHD medication for the white & wealthy, & leaves the rest of is with ineffective treatment, condescension, & medical trauma. A system that robbed us of healthcare.

Someone who identified themselves as a "mental health worker" once replied to my tweets abt being angry over my misdx & mistx by saying that my anger indicated an "affective disorder." I'm done being told that my justified anger at a system which harmed me is itself an illness

I've talked a lot about ADHD, but I'm also autistic. Part of my autism is getting stuck on/ruminating on things that are unjust, unfair, discriminatory. It's so abhorrent to me that my mind cannot let it go, & my ADHD mental hyperactivity just amps that up to eleven

If I had the care I needed, if anyone saw me as a person rather than a problem, maybe I would still be working today. Maybe I wouldn't have lost my 20s to chronic pain & only discovered my endo bc I got pregnant. Maybe I wouldn't be learning basic ADHD survival skills at 33

Before I filed for SSDI, I showed up at a building at 7am, waited in line for 2hrs, & got assigned a MH provider for poor, uninsured people. They started every appt by saying they don't prescribe controlled substances. Before we even arrive, the scope of our diagnosis is limited

If the (young, inexperienced, low-income clinic) psych who misdxed me w bipolar had been able to see me as a person who could conceivably be ADHD/autistic & screened me, they would've found my symptoms & history align w ADHD/A, not BD. They didn't, & I'm still paying for it

When poor & marginalized #ADHD-ers & #autistic people are misdiagnosed with mood, personality, or behavior disorders, it doesn't just prevent them from getting the care they need- it often prevents them from getting any care at all bc of the tremendous stigma of these conditions

I couldn't find an @AmPsychFdn apology to women, but the abuses historically & continually heaped upon #ADHD & #autistic women certainly requires its own (fawning, toothless) statement of apology. ADHD/A women are still overwhelmingly misdxed w mood & personality disorders

I'd encourage people to read the whole thing because... it's a lot. A lot of nice words, a lot of racial justice set dressing, and a total unwillingness to see the way racism still guides the practice of mental healthcare to this day. Black ADHD/autistic people deserve better.

There's a lot of nice words in the @AmPsychFdn racism apology, but they use a lot of past tense- as if this was a thing the mental health field did in the past, rather than a thing they continue to do. Black #ADHD-ers & autistic people are still overwhelmingly being misdxed w ODD https://t.co/zGsl25e9HQ

Last year the American Psychological Association released a statement titled "Apology to People of Color for APA’s Role in Promoting, Perpetuating, and Failing to Challenge Racism, Racial Discrimination, and Human Hierarchy in U.S." https://t.co/9mx5Hdk1su

Medical drug prohibition exacerbated the discrimination experienced by poor & marginalized people by threatening to imprison doctors who treat "high risk" patients. Those patients ~just happen~ to be Black, women, poor, trans, disabled- ppl traumatized by a world hostile to them

There are a combination of things at play- individual mental health providers have biases, the field as a whole seems entirely unwilling to learn about how women & BIPoC experience ADHD/autism, & now a handy little algorithm exists to allow doctors to discriminate more discreetly

But I often wonder- if I hadn't been misdxed w bipolar, if I hadn't been given a diagnosis which is (unfairly) associated w dishonesty & substance use disorder, would doctors have discovered my endometriosis a decade earlier? Could I have kept working instead of going on SSDI?

To be absolutely clear- even if I were bipolar, this would be inexcusable. Human beings are capable of more than one health concern at a time. Depression, anxiety, any mental illness shouldn't be seen as evidence a patient's pain isn't real & doesn't require diagnosis & treatment

When I was misdxed as bipolar, I was also receiving care for back & pelvic pain. Doctors were running tests, & I received 30 5mg norco (opioids) per month. After misdiagnosis, the testing stopped. The meds stopped. Every concern I brought up became "depression" or "anxiety"

Returning to the misdx of ADHD as bipolar, borderline, or ODD- those diagnoses & the medications that are used for them are interpreted as "high risk." People w a BD, BPD, or ODD diagnosis are considered likely to misuse prescription drugs- locking them out of effective ADHD care

These disparities existed long before the NarxCare predictive risk algorithm began collecting our decontextualized data points & turning them into a "who deserves care" score. But with NarxCare, doctors don't have to discriminate- the algorithm does it for them, no muss no fuss

Doctors- esp on twitter dot com- talk a good game about providing quality care to every patient regardless of race, gender, or income. They say the right words about healthcare inequality. But the truth remains: women, BIPoC, & poor ppl are not getting the help we need & deserve

This is a long shot, but I'd sincerely like to ask #psychiatrist twitter to evaluate this: if you're treating patients w stimulants for ADHD, how many are poor vs financially stable? How many are women vs men? How many are Black vs white? How many are low wage  vs white collar?

And as bleak as the disparities are for women, they are astounding for Black patients. Black patients are not only far less likely to receive testing or medication for virtually any health concern, but are actually more likely to be knowingly subjected to inferior treatments https://t.co/gy4ah2AEWF

Or look at chronic pain: Women are 70% of chronic pain patients, but are less likely to receive further testing or opioids than men are. It takes an average of 8 to 10 yrs to be dxed w endometriosis. I spent 10+ yrs seeking dx for endo, but was told my pain was just depression

Consider this: men are more likely to have a heart attack, but women are more likely to die from a heart attack. This happens for a couple reasons:

1. Doctors are only taught how to recognize heart attacks in men

2. Doctors routinely dismiss women's health concerns as anxiety

Women, BIPoC, & poor ppl have been (and continue to be) locked out of ADHD diagnosis & treatment. Medical misogyny, racism, & classism are widespread issues. Who is believed & treated has always been down to who is considered trustworthy- especially when ~drugs~ are involved

Going through bipolar & mood disorder questionnaires, nearly every single question can be answered affirmatively by an ADHD person. Frustration? Yep. Mood shifts? Yep. So hyper you get in trouble? Yep. Can't stop talking? Yep. Impulsivity w sex or money? Big ol yep. https://t.co/zwmoqiwBZK

Several times I tried to discuss my rocking, swaying, insomnia, messiness, restlessness, with psychs, & the result was always "that's anxiety, that's depression, that's bipolar disorder." But  even with four mental health diagnoses, they still didn't cover all of my symptoms

Many who don't fit the ADHD stereotype have no idea that symptoms like disorganization, "girl" varieties of hyperactivity (tapping, fidgeting, skin-picking), hyperfocus, delayed sleep phase, restlessness, etc, are symptoms at all- we're told they are personal quirks or deficits

If you aren't looking for ADHD (or are trying to avoid ADHD bc you can't or don't want to prescribe a controlled substance), ADHD symptoms can easily be labeled bipolar. ADHD emotional dysregulation can be called "mood swings." Hyperfocus can be considered "mania."

I was 18 when I was misdiagnosed with bipolar disorder in 2006. In that same year my dad took off & my childhood home got foreclosed- it's safe to say I was in a fair bit of distress. Nobody screened me for ADHD or autism, which should be standard practice if a psych suspects BD

Psychs overwhelming still seem to believe that most ADHDers are hyperactive white adolescent boys from financially secure families. They still cling to "boy=hyperactive, girl=inattentive" stereotypes. When ADHDers show up who don't fit the stereotype, we get sorted... elsewhere

Despite my best friend being ADHD growing up, despite my brother & both male cousins being diagnosed with ADHD as kids, I never considered ADHD for myself bc the stereotype is a hyperactive white middle class+ boy. It was a condition wealthy white kids had, not poor kids like me

There's a reason pundits endlessly wail over the increase in ADHD diagnosis in kids, but not over the massive increase in bipolar disorder: drugs. If a kid is barely conscious due to bipolar medication oh well, at least they can't get ~high~. But stimulants? Those are no-no drugs

A staggering number of AFAB ADHD/autistics I talk to have either been misdiagnosed w bipolar disorder or borderline personality disorder. A staggering number of Black ADHD/autistics have been misdiagnosed w "Oppositional Defiant Disorder." This is anecdotal, but compelling to me

In 2010, NPR reported that the number of children diagnosed w bipolar had risen 4,000% since the mid-90s Still no media kerfuffle over children being ~overdiagnosed~ with BD tho. So what happened? I don't think it's a stretch to suggest it was women & BIPoC seeking ADHD diagnosis https://t.co/FHktIXJOQt

In the paper I screenshotted, the 40-fold growth in child BD diagnosis happened from 1994-1995 to 2002-2003. Unrelated I'm sure, but in the 90s boys were 9x more likely to be diagnosed ADHD than girls were (and those boys were overwhelmingly white)

Why have rates of bipolar diagnosis grown so rapidly, especially in kids? Why is nobody lamenting the ~overdiagnosis~ of bipolar disorder in kids? Jk I know why: it's bc diagnosing kids w bipolar allows psychs to avoid prescribing ADHD meds to poor kids, girls & children of color https://t.co/FRoZTGODC4

@fochti That's exactly what happened to me. The ~fun~ thing is- 10% of US adults have ADHD, only 2% have any form of bipolar disorder, & cyclothymia is considered rare among people w BD. But that was somehow considered more likely than ADHD despite family history of ADHD & none for BD

Not gonna lie, we're watching Sky High right now because of the first ten minutes of your video on it (didn't want to spoil it). Almost choked when the main character wore a shirt with the number 88 on it. It's somehow even worse than I was anticipating https://t.co/uTQWafJxyC

@MeekAstyrsen Go for it!

@PaperOfWoodward I can relate, before I knew about ADHD I had all sorts of made up names to describe my symptoms. I'd call hyperactivity & sensory issues "body anxiety," describe my hyperactive pacing as "revving up," and meltdowns were "going feral"

This is really important. Mental hyperactivity, hypersensitivity (both sensory & emotional), the persistent feeling of bodily distress & even perhaps dissociation from trying to suppress your hyperactivity, these are all very much underexamined parts of the hyperactive experience https://t.co/UgnWkoOdVR

I should also mention that Black ADHDers are not just socially or academically punished for their hyperactivity, they are also criminalized and killed for hyperactivity. A Black man hype-pacing near a store (esp if vocal stimming) may very well end up dead for being "suspicious."

Obviously this perception of "anything but hyperactivity" harms us diagnostically, but it also profoundly harms us personally. I didn't know why my body felt like this, or how to help myself feel better. I consciously squashed my overt hyperactivity even though it hurts me

Hyperactivity is pathologized in women & BIPoC. In women it's taken as anxiety, trauma, maybe bipolar/borderline. In Black people it's taken as "Oppositional Defiant Disorder." Hyperactivity is seen as the domain of little white boys exclusively, so we must have some other issue

There's also the misconception that hyperactivity is strictly physical, but most are also *mentally* hyperactive. Some of us are hyperverbal. The hyperactive white adolescent boy is a stereotype, not the totality of hyperactivity. But even psychs interpret our hype as illness

I think daydreaming itself may be partially a form of dissociation AFAB people adopt to survive the expectation that we be still & quiet. I was kicked out of class constantly for talking & moving. I learned to go somewhere else in my head & that helped, but I was lost in class

My hyperactivity is pronounced. It always has been. I rock, sway, tap, pick my skin, bite my lips, tap my feet. In between steps of tasks or to prepare for tasks I walk back and forth daydreaming, like I have to rev up my brain. I was told it was anxiety. It was hyperactivity.

I see a lot of AFAB ppl who think of themselves as primarily/exclusively inattentive. Then they mention the fidgeting, chatter, feeling like an overwound guitar string or kettle w the vent blocked, skin-picking, lip-biting, nail chewing- the hyperactivity we're permitted to show

We hear a lot of "boys are hyperactive, girls are inattentive," to this day, but it's wrong. The majority of ADHDers- regardless of gender- are combined type. Those of us who grew up placed in the "girl" box are alienated from our hyperactivity bc we aren't allowed to express it

Growing up a girl, I heard a lot of "boys will be boys" when boys were being loud & rambunctious. I was also loud & rambunctious (& hyperactive), but I was chastised bc girls are ~supposed~ to be "more mature." I learned I couldn't express my excess energy the way boys do

As a kid I'd cover my legs in icy hot & wrap them as tightly as I could in ace bandages, bc it was the only way to get my restless, squirming, achy legs to calm down enough for me to lay down (& still not fall asleep til 2am). I was told it was growing pains. It was hyperactivity

It's exhausting to deal with. I have to manage my body before I can even think about doing anything. I take kratom, I need hours to wake up, and I still don't feel like my brain works until around noon bc (like many of us) I have delayed sleep phase- my body clock runs late

When I figured out that my "stuck on the couch, can't get anything done, but also can't relax because my body is like a raw nerve overexposed to electricity" feelings were hyperactivity & sensory issues, it blew my mind. I legit thought everyone felt like this all the time.

One of the worst ADHD/autism experiences is being hyperactive or having sensory issues, feeling that constant energy & tension, the distress from your body, but you're deep in executive dysfunction so all you can do is flop around on the couch watching YouTube videos & stimming

I'm very bad at keeping up with who is following me (and also just life in general) but please if you're Black, Indigenous, Latinx & ADHD and/or autistic, drop me a comment here & I will enthusiastically follow & retweet. Systems are built to fail us- we have to reach each other

I've read that one! I think it was an @ADHD_Alien comic about rejection sensitive dysphoria that first got me interested in learning about ADHD bc I'd never seen it described before. I also think daydreaming is part of how ADHDers conceptualize time bc we don't see it how NTs do https://t.co/JxQv5KYozh

I'm gonna shut up now, even though I could go on and on for hours. This thread has gone all over the place. But I'm really touched and grateful for all of the affirmation, the sharing of personal experiences. I'm grateful for an ADHD community that has embraced me as I am

Poor ppl, BIPoC, women need a better understanding of ADHD, and a full-throated defense of our right to dx & tx. We must be unapologetically loud in advocating for our misdiagnosed/undiagnosed people, lobbying for change to a system that only sees one valid stereotype of ADHD

This is unforgivably long, but inequality is baked into how we treat ADHD. There's a clear line between who gets to say "I'm ADHD," & who is just terminally a worthless loser. Diagnosis is the first step to reclaiming what a failed system took from us, but it's not the last step

This leads to misdiagnosis & lack of treatment. It preserves the safe, legal amphetamines for the white, wealthy, & respectable, while the rest of us scramble, struggle, attempt suicide, seek out illicit substances (maybe OD), and/or go to prison to make profit for someone else

So what does NarxCare have to do w ADHD treatment? Everything. When your state mandates that your psych check the database before prescribing, your psych is evaluating your score instead of your condition. The trauma of being poor & marginalized makes you too "high risk" for care

Based on this info, we can deduce that women are penalized for surviving abuse & sexual assault (bc trauma is considered a risk factor), and Black people are penalized for being overpoliced & disproportionately arrested/imprisoned (bc crime is considered a risk factor)

That being said, we can make sound guesses based on various drug risk score systems that pre-date it, as well as the wealth of research on racial bias in parole & sentencing predictive risk algorithms. Predictive risk algorithms consistently penalize the poor & marginalized.

NarxCare is a "black box" algorithm, it is software belonging to a for-profit company (Equifax bought the company last year for around $2 billion- your medical data is very valuable). Being proprietary, we don't know how it makes determinations on who is too "high risk" for care https://t.co/BIz8iwgo9l

ADHD dx & treatment is paywalled. ADHD tx in the US is largely governed by a predictive risk algorithm- NarxCare takes your criminal justice, EMS, & other data & turns it into a score determining what meds you can access. It is fundamentally biased against the poor & marginalized

Expecting individuals to succeed within a system designed to fail them isn't logical or rational, it's cruelty dressed up as personal responsibility. I have considerable faults, but they exist within the context of capitalism & ableism, the failure to see people like me as people

Should I be better? Sure, whatever "better" means. But the bigger questions are- why did I get misdiagnosed, why did the system fail me, why is it failing so many women misdxed w bipolar or borderline & so many Black ppl misdxed with "Oppositional Defiant Disorder."

By the time I was misdxed w bipolar, my brother & both (male) cousins had been dxed w ADHD. I have no family history of bipolar or mental illness, just ADHD. But bc of my gender & socioeconomic position, I got misdxed. At 33 I'm trying to get support I should've had as a kid

I was (like a lot of ADHD/autistic women) misdxed with bipolar at 18. I never really related to what I read about it, but I would get furious when my partner & mother would say I'm not bipolar, bc clearly something is going on w me. But bipolar couldn't help me understand myself

Post-diagnosis (and post-healthcare trauma), I've had to deal with a lot of grief, anger, sadness, yearning, fury- the whole post-diagnosis grab bag. But as tough as that world of could-have-beens is, I'm glad I know. ADHD & autism helped me understand myself for the first time

Its tremendously painful to constantly be told that you should be better, do better, just apply yourself & pull yourself up by your bootstraps. It's like being dropped in the middle of the ocean & told you can easily swim home. You can't. That's not an excuse, it's just reality.

Dunno if I addressed the "undiagnosed" issue, got distracted by my own train of thought 🤷‍♀️ Anyways, being undiagnosed left me feeling broken & hating myself for not just magically being better. Now I know that being untreated means I don't have what I need to survive this world

I still have a huge lingering cloud of self-hatred bc in my mind I have all the things I need & should be able to meet societal expectations instead of living in poverty. But knowing about ADHD/A helps me to understand why someone like me struggles to succeed in a world like this

Part of why I started using my Twitter account is that I started learning about ADHD & autism, couldn't stop talking about it, my partner was exhausted by my constant analysis (fair, it's... a lot), & I needed somewhere to get all these thoughts out & process my ADHD/autism

I'm a quick learner. I'm hyperverbal & hyperactive. I enthusiastically pursue interests but I need to be able to talk out steps out loud with someone else. History has taught me that nobody wants to hear me talk that much. I end up stuck in my head, out of touch w the real world

Actually, it has been life-saving. For all my (moderate) skills, I struggle to conceive of the future bc my brain divides time into "now" & "not now." I struggle to understand consequences. My ability to plan steps is poor, but my ability to daydream possibilities is excellent

Knowing about my ADHD, understanding why I'm constantly being torn in different directions, why I've been determined to be a midwife, ARG creator, jewelry maker, teacher, author, director, woodworker, academic, etc, without ever becoming those things, has been a gift to me

I have plenty of useful skills (most at the low-moderate level bc I can't stick with anything long enough to gain mastery), but the way employment & survival works in our society makes my boundless interest & smattering of unrelated skills into a deficit instead of a benefit

before diagnosis, before I poured myself into learning about ADHD, I thought that about myself- I must be lazy, unmotivated, worthless to society. Knowing about ADHD helped me understand that I live in a society which makes no allowance for- or actively punishes- neurodivergence

I've seen a bunch of people say that it doesn't change once you're diagnosed- you're totally right. I'm 33, got diagnosed at 32, still can't get treatment, so I'm kinda existing in this in-between state where it's been confirmed, it's real, but nobody treats it like it's real

But I'm very very grateful for y'all for reaffirming that the shit I'm dealing with is common for ADHD/autistic people. The medical gaslighting is intense, and it makes you doubt your own reality, but when I hear "thanks for putting this into words" etc, it confirms my reality

I've been screenshotting my big tweets, like someday I can show them to a psych and be like "see how fucking ADHD & autistic I am! See me as a person! Help me!" But the idea of a psych doing literally anything beyond saying "hmm, must be depression/anxiety/PTSD" seems unrealistic

Having popular Twitter threads about ADHD & autism is weird, because on one hand I've got dozens or hundreds of ADHD/Aers liking, retweeting, thanking me for putting something into words, & that's wonderful & affirming. But nobody will treat my ADHD, so it's... bittersweet?

Now if I were in a family with resources, diagnosed & treated for my ADHD, with a safety net to fall back on, maybe I could just leap from thing to thing and stumble ass-backwards into success as a ~bold entrepreneur~, but I'm poor so I just have a pile of hobby equipment

As a kid it's normal to have lots of interests, to daydream about all sorts of careers, but eventually my friends all settled on one thing they wanted to do. Meanwhile, all I could do was daydream about myself already established in something cool that I just kinda fell into

I remember in like 3rd grade maybe, we had to do these tests to see what careers best suited our personalities. Unsurprisingly, mine suggested the arts, but I was furious the entire time bc it seemed ridiculous to expect 3rd graders (or anyone) to pick 1 thing to do w their lives

The ADHDer in me wants to be a Jack of all trades, to continuously learn and explore new things, gain a moderate amount of skill, keep moving on. The autistic in me wants to be a specialist, to make myself an authority on whatever I'm currently interested in. It's hard to manage

There's also conflict for me in that I'm ADHD & autistic, so sometimes a short term hyperfocus turns into a long term fixation. Except I never know when that will be, and even with fixations they only tend to last 5 or 6 years before I hit the cap of what I can do/learn & move on

I want to be an author, I want to be an advocate for poor disabled people, I want to do woodworking, teaching, jewelry, youtube, etc. I never stop wanting to do things, it just falls apart when I have to *plan* to do it instead of just daydreaming about already being it

It's not great in a system where you have to sell your labor for a wage. A lot of ADHDers do art or youtube or jewelry/crafts where we can change up projects & do new things. But I will always be aware that someday I will go to do this thing I love & just feel burdened by it

It's hard to explain that I have two modes: hyperfocus, where I work harder & longer, am totally preoccupied with that thing in a way that annoys or worries neurotypicals. Or non-hyperfocus, where doing literally anything takes every ounce of energy I have & then I melt down

It is very, very difficult to plan for a career you love when your devotion to a particular activity could suddenly die off in a few days or weeks. As ADHDers we tend to pick either jobs that provide an adrenaline rush, or jobs where we're doing something different all the time

When you're undiagnosed w ADHD people take your lack of forward motion, your lack of career success, as evidence of laziness & lack of interest/ambition. In my experience, it's more like choice paralysis. I've daydreamed dozens of careers I'd be good at- I just can't stick to one

A symptom of bipolar is grandiosity. I think for ADHDers our hyperfocus & unrealistic daydreaming is mistaken for grandiosity, like we must be grandiose if we think are so good at [HF] we could have success with it. But for ADHD/Aers, it's not about us, its the joy of the project

got distracted by woodworking, checked Twitter, realized I had the last post ready... Anyways a big tip in distinguishing bipolar vs ADHD is the mood duration. I feel better during hyperfocus bc I'm less painfully aware of myself, but my big moods last hours or minutes, not days

CW: suicide
.
.
People with bipolar are more likely to have suicidal thoughts/attempts when they are manic. I have ideation, but it only happens during deep, sudden holes of depression which are directly related to real world circumstances & fade relatively quickly

To be fair to psychs, this cycle (especially when combined with another cycle- menstruation), can give a false impression of bipolar disorder. But there are major differences, and the refusal to screen for ADHD & autism when a psych suspects bipolar is, in my view, malpractice

There's also a downswing, when one hyperfocus has died a sudden death but theres no other dopamine node available to mine, no other hyperfocus in the pipeline. I feel deflated. Not sad, exactly, but the things I need to do feel harder to accomplish, I'm more withdrawn & fatigued

For me, I feel the best when I have a New Interesting Thing to throw all of my energy behind. It's refreshing to feel focused, competent, to play in a new sandbox. Hyperfocus takes my mind off of the discomfort of hyperactivity & sensory issues. I'm always hoping hyperfocus hits

The cycle of ADHD executive dysfunction/hyperfocus is so tricky to get correctly diagnosed. For me, it was misdiagnosed as bipolar disorder. For some, it's misdiagnosed as depression & anxiety, but it's poorly understood (even sometimes to those of us who experience it)

You spend years dealing w symptoms that impact your ability to spend meaningful time with family & friends, work, do basic household tasks, to live. You do what you're supposed to do- seek help so you can feel better. Except the doctor won't test you, just says you're depressed

It's awful to refuse to treat patients bc the algorthim says their group does drugs. Collective punishment is... not great. But the deeper impact of the "no legal drugs for poors" policy is that poor/marginalized patients have to doctor themselves while MDs keep their hands clean

If you have a bad score & you're in pain, you're treated as tho you showed up w a bag marked "drugs please," even when you never ask for drugs & repeatedly beg doctors to run tests to try to diagnose you. An authority figure repeatedly denying your reality can kinda fuck you up

But it's not just about meds. That's certainly important- ask anyone whose pain or ADHD is not being managed- but the most cruel & horrifying thing is the way Drs treat patients who have bad scores (on a predictive risk algorithm that penalizes you for being poor, a woman, BIPoC)

Doctors are encouraged to deny medications to ~certain~ patients as part of "opioid-sparing" policy shaped by faulty data about illicit vs prescription overdose death. They're heavily pressured to only prescribe to the white, wealthy, & respectable- the people who ~deserve~ help

That being said, the income gap between doctors & patients is usually significant, doctors can have substantial personal biases against the poor & marginalized, & some doctors have eagerly deputized themselves to singlehandedly stop "The Opioid Crisis" one "drug-seeker" at a time

I don't blame doctors as a class necessarily, a lot of the cruelty they are encouraged or even mandated to participate in is truly not within their control. The DEA has so thoroughly infiltrated healthcare that treating ~certain~ patients gets you arrested & your life destroyed

Misogyny, racism, classism, ableism, transphobia- the entire variety pack of shit-flavored oppression- is still alive in countries w universal (in theory) healthcare, but the US for-profit system is designed around tiered ~healthcare access~ in a way that guarantees inequality

It would be very cool if women, BIPoC, & poor people didn't immediately get tossed into the "drug-seeking" or "attention-seeking" pile while seeking healthcare, and instead were assumed to be actual human beings with medical needs seeking assistance from trained professionals

We can be so desperate to avoid punishment, criticism, or rejection that we act against our own self-interest to prevent upset- staying w abusive partners or bad friends, making excuses for people who violate our boundaries, working ourselves to death to avoid being called "lazy"

#ADHD/#autistic folks get punished for being frank about our needs/upsets, we're subjected to frustration & passive aggressive anger we don't understand, we get anxiety, RSD, shame, & fury. When I get really upset I shut down & go nonspeaking bc I can't even form words in my head

I got so much passive aggressive, read-between-the-lines anger that eventually I started doing it too, bc it seemed like the only way I was allowed to be angry. When I speak up about things that upset me I get emotional, & ppl use it against me. I've learned to shut up about it

often when neurotypicals are upset with you, you are expected to read between the lines. I got a lot of "you know what you did wrong" responses or just stony silence til the yelling started. I often did not know what I did wrong, so it was torture trying to figure it out

For ADHD, anxiety helps to limit impulsivity or brute force your attention back to where it needs to be, but there's also a specific kind of social anxiety- constant anticipation that someone will tell you you're being annoying, lazy, did something wrong, didn't respond correctly

ADHD gets you so distracted or hyperfocused on a thing (never the correct thing), that you end up genuinely baffled that someone is upset with you. Like yes, sorry I forgot to vacuum, I forgot floors exist bc I spent 3 hours looking at rotary bits I shouldn't be spending money on

When you routinely get punished for your neurodivergence over the course of decades, you learn to expect punishment- even if you haven't done anything wrong, even if you think you're doing alright for once. It's like the world exists to be mad at you for being the way you are

I spend hours walking back & forth in my dining room, just thinking, daydreaming, ruminating. My internal world is a lot bigger (and more interesting) than my external world. But I'm an adult, a parent, I'm supposed to do [TASKS], not daydream. I'm always waiting to be admonished

There's a very specific trauma of being neurodivergent & constantly being told you're being weird, annoying, off-putting, being punished for messing up. Being told the way your body & brain are is wrong & bad- you can't rock, pace, vocal stim, talk excessively about the Titanic

My partner & I are both ADHD & autistic, we're painfully familiar with this cycle, but often still when one of us melts down in frustration or self-hatred over what we haven't gotten done, the other gets depressed, or angry, or goes into fawning people-pleaser mode. It's tough.

Anxiety serves a useful function in ADHDers- snapping us into focus when needed (driving,childcare), acting as an alarm to let us know we've transgressed a social norm, producing adrenaline so we can do things. But the anxiety of the upset>confusion>RSD>shame cycle is destructive

That cycle of screwing up, not knowing how/why or not being able to fix it on your own, suffering social/emotional/financial consequences of screwing up, making ppl around you upset in ways you don't understand, reflexively thinking you're in trouble- its persistent & harmful

I'm not always the target of the anger/frustration/disappointment, but I have a lifetime of exp being ND & doing things that annoy others, not doing things correctly, just not doing things, so over time you learn that it's safer to just assume you are the problem- you often are

For me this goes one of two ways- either I fall into the depression pit for a few minutes or hours, or I get furious bc I can't figure out what I did wrong & I'm tired of always screwing things up. The slightest hint of judgement or rejection is so painful it gets hard to breathe

When you go undxed w #ADHD & #autism til adulthood, you can identify behaviors indicating someone's angry, but you can't discern the target or intention of that anger so your rejection sensitive dysphoria goes into overdrive. You're always the screw-up, so they must be mad at you

I'm just saying I was told everything from rocking to tapping to feeling overwhelmed w energy to restless legs, that that was all anxiety. But it wasn't. Anxiety is a big part of my life, but it lives in the moment. My body discomfort, hyperactivity, sensory stuff is a constant

I do wonder if some of the physical manifestations of anxiety in ADHDers might really be sensory issues, dyspraxia, hyperactivity- especially in populations who have been historically underdiagnosed with ADHD/A, like AFAB people, BIPoC, poor people

I regularly find myself grateful that my anxiety limits my impulsivity, snaps me back to attention when I start thinking about my own shit or see something cool or get Barbie Girl stuck in my head. My anxiety tries to warn me of impending doom, and I need that heads up

The way anxiety functions in ADHDers is very different than GAD. It's intensely situational, it's in response to panic because your life is chaos, everything is a mess, you spent four days carving a stick instead of vacuuming what the fuck is wrong with you. It helps us survive.

My partner & I used to regularly rage clean- pick a fight, get mad as hell at each other, and then that adrenaline would push us forward, break us out of executive dysfunction, and we could finally get some housecleaning done. We've had to adapt since having a kid, but it's tough

When you're inattentive anxiety becomes a kind of alarm, letting you know you could very well fuck up big time and you need to pay attention right fucking now. Anxiety produces adrenaline, and often the only time ADHDers can be productive is when we're up against the wall

I know I'm supposed to want to be free of anxiety, but my anxiety is attached to my ADHD & autism. Anxiety has helped me obey social rules when I didn't understand them, anxiety keeps me from getting distracted by a cool tree while w my kid, keeps me paying attention to the road

There's also the unfortunate issue that CBT is very widely performed by practitioners who view it as a cure-all or have a poor understanding of its uses & principles. A lot of things can be called "CBT" while being at best a poor approximation. Poorly done CBT can be its own harm

For me, I think CBT would be traumatizing, because so much of my life has been just begging someone, anyone to believe that I am in pain. And now in the last few years, that I am ADHD & autistic. So therapy to train me to stop believing what I know to be true sounds like torture

I dunno, I've talked to some BPDers and they seem to believe CBT is useful, and I'm inclined to believe them, but I'm always curious who has tried CBT for what- and if it helped them- so if anyone wants to discuss that please feel free

But also, y'know, changing your thoughts isn't going to do much if the issue is a physical problem & not a perception or reaction problem. Even if you have a big emotional response to it, pain is the trigger. Telling you to ignore that & focus on changing behavior is just cruel

I've had doctors tell me I just need to stop complaining about pain, stop talking about it, stop responding to it. I'm autistic & ADHD, complaint (often in the form of comedic hyperbole) & discussion is how I process & understand things, myself included. Taking that away hurts me

When a person is in pain- serious, persistent pain- and you put them through a therapy which tells them essentially "you're doing this to yourself, just think better & the torture will end" that is massively traumatizing. You aren't undoing harmful habits, you're just gaslighting

Pain is a subjective experience. There is no way to measure how much pain a person feels. People considered overly sensitive to pain may have a brain that struggles to regulate signals- i.e. chronic pain is more common in ADHDers & autistics. But even then it's still pain.

The one that pisses me off the most is using CBT for pain management. This is done with the belief that some large percentage of pain patients are "catastrophizing," which makes their pain seem worse than it is. It's the modern "hysteria-" still overwhelmingly stigmatizing women

And it's tricky bc I've always said CBT can be useful for some people, for some issues, so I don't want to dismiss it, but I also feel like I should scream from the rooftops about the way people (and I'm betting mostly women & BIPoC) are being harmed by misuse of CBT

It's a great way to train people to think that their wants and their needs are unrealistic, that the distress they feel isn't caused by a medical/mental health issue or the desperation of their material conditions, it's simply the wrong frame of mind & changing that can "fix" you

With the exception of patients who benefit from it, CBT is the modern individualistic bootstrap nightmare you get when working class people just get harm after harm, exhaustion, poor pay, no healthcare, vacation, sick pay, & just have to ~wellness~ your way through the muck

I guess I shouldn't speak for BPDers, I've just talked to some who firmly believe CBT helps them, & I appreciate that I have at best a rudimentary understanding of BPD so I defer to them on that. But mental health uses CBT as a cure-all, & it's harming patients every day

Thinking about CBT & once again feeling frustrated that a helpful tool *when used correctly* is now a source of trauma & anxiety for so many people with chronic pain, ADHD, autism- things that CBT can't help with. Meanwhile people it could help (like BPDers) can barely access it

Not terribly surprising that girls and women are chronically underdiagnosed & undertreated for #ADHD, like yeah, cutting off half the ADHD criteria and willfully misreading symptoms based on nothing but sex assigned at birth tends to result in shit like that

But for me, the problem was twofold: I was trying very hard to suppress my hyperactivity in order to stop getting in trouble, and when my hyperactivity did burst out (which was often) it was always attributed to something else, because of course ~girls~ can't be ~hyperactive~

Even cis men get screwed by these enforced ADHD gender roles. My partner is a white cis man, he has ADHD, but he also presents largely inattentive, without a lot of characteristic "male" expressions of hyperactivity. He didn't get dxed until I started talking abt ADHD in *women*

I want to remind everyone that "man" & "woman" are meant to refer to how an ADHDer is perceived to be, what gender box their family, school, medical care perceives them to be. I can't speak for trans ppl but I'm sure they get additional layers of weird gender shit thrown at them

We have to work so hard to suppress all those bad, weird, wrong-for-our-gender things bc we cannot get away with them the way boys can. Doctors say ADHD in women is "subtle," but it's more like "nobody bothers looking for it, & if you accidentally find it just say it's anxiety."

The little nugget of wisdom in mental health education is: boys are hyperactive-impulsive, girls are inattentive. Nevermind that the majority of ADHDers (& majority of women) are combined type. Hyperactivity in boys is recognized as ADHD, in girls it's called anxiety, BD, or BPD

We try like hell to limit how loud we are, our movement, our hypersensitivity to light, noise, touch, how emotionally big we are, how angry we get. I succeeded at limiting my movement by dissociating- daydreaming- to escape the discomfort of stillness. I suspect many AFAB ppl do

In the US the saying is "boys will be boys," Meaning boys are supposed to be rambunctious, rowdy, loud, messy, a bit aggressive, & you can't discipline that out of them. Girls don't get that tho, we get "girls mature younger/more quickly." When we're hyperactive there is blowback

With #autism the (bullshit) stereotype is: "girls aren't autistic." With #ADHD the stereotype is that boys/men are hyperactive-impulsive, & girls/women are inattentive. This mistaken idea is ferociously enforced. ADHD diagnosis & treatment are gendered in a profoundly harmful way
