even when I'm legitimately feeling anxiety, it's often tied to hyperactivity or sensory issues. When I can't filter out any sounds in my environment I quickly get overloaded, which leads to anxiety. When I can't get up & walk it starts to feel like my nerve endings are on fire

it's even more frustrating bc I do have anxiety in some situations, but it often takes me a bit to figure out it's anxiety bc since I was a teenager "anxiety" has meant "any weird thing you do that isn't depression," so sorting these things out (esp in real time) is a nightmare

No breathing or relaxation exercises can make me able to just magically stay still & quiet, bc my constant movement isn't anxiety. My body wants to stay in motion. When I have to force myself to stay still & quiet I turn to daydreaming & bottle up my distress til it explodes

misdiagnosing my hyperactivity & sensory issues as "anxiety" cut me off from effective treatment, but it also robbed me of the ability to manage them on my own. I made myself not do the things that make my body/brain feel better, bc they made people around me uncomfortable

I've been pacing the same 8 ft of floor in my kitchen for the last 30 mins, & I feel so much better than I felt when I was stuck on the couch earlier. My body feels less like a steam engine about to explode, I can think more clearly, I have momentum but the second I stop it stops
hard to believe this started as a tweet about woodworking lol

Same thing w walking. I've always done this thing where I pace over the same area while thinking/daydreaming/ruminating for hours sometimes. My mental hyperactivity is tied to my physical hyperactivity. Everyone has always considered it "anxiety," but to me it's just comfortable

My partner started working from home a decade ago, & when that happened he thought I was constantly anxious, bc he'd come out during the day & see me rocking. I'd get annoyed bc he was constantly like "you okay?" & I was fine. Took me a while to realize he thought it was anxiety

every person who knows me knows I sway side to side (sometimes quite vigorously) when I stand, but almost nobody sees me rock back & forth when I sit bc I got choked for it at school in 5th or 6th grade, forced myself to stop doing it in public, & my daydreaming got worse instead

My partner is also ADHD so we had to make a rule that we can't have our phones out or do other things while trying to watch TV together, or we'd constantly get lost in other things & eventually fight about feeling ignored. It's a bit better since I started letting myself rock tho

In retrospect the fact that I have a big list of alternating hobbies I can do with my hands (sewing, jewelry, woodworking) and I always do them while watching TV should've been a big clue that I'm ADHD. Seriously, its torture when I do family TV time & can't do anything but watch

I don't believe "Oppositional Defiant Disorder" is real. I believe ODD is the diagnosis they give Black, Indigenous, & Latine kids when they meet the criteria for ADHD/A but a Dr doesn't want to prescribe ADHD meds, or put in any extra effort, so it becomes a ~behavior~ issue

I'm not Black & don't want to speak for Black ADHD/autistic ppl, but I also can't pretend "woman" is a category exclusive to white women. A Black ADHD/A woman must battle the trope that women can't be angry, while also being considered angry by default due to racist stereotypes

I got sidetracked bc I'm still very fucking angry about that incident, but it kinda helps my point. This only gets more complicated when Black, Indigenous, & Latine ADHD/A ppl (especially women & girls) seek care. A Black woman is bumping up against two conflicting BS stereotypes

My last psych insisted that as a woman she couldn't discriminate against women w ADHD/autism. She refused to discuss my ADHD w me, but told my partner that I had "adult-onset" ADHD (nope), was lying for drugs, & I'd never get treatment bc "she doesn't even work or go to school"

The best part is- my partner & I went to the same psych. It's not a bad apples situation, it's persistent discrimination. The slightest frustration on my part & I am considered hysterical or "drug-seeking." I am not allowed the agency to simply get mad at my own mistreatment

I've been begging for help w these issues since childhood- all it got me was a bipolar misdiagnosis & 15+ yrs of ineffective or harmful treatment. My last psych refused to discuss my ADHD diagnosis w me, prescribed antidepressants, & when I cried she accused me of "attacking" her

My partner is a cis man, & he sought ADHD screening after I spent 3 years rambling about why I thought I was ADHD/autistic. He was easily diagnosed & began stimulants. He is allowed to be frustrated, irritated, incredulous, to express doubt w his doctor. He's allowed to be angry.

when I say "man" and "woman" I am referring to how a patient is perceived in their family, in school, in a doctor's office. I am not saying that this perception is always correct, or that genders have hardwired traits, just that our access to care is influenced by gender norms

When ADHD/autistic women present with this same anger, this same inability to regulate their emotional state, it is seen as... sick? As wrong, aggressive, even dangerous. As something unnatural, which *must* be the result of some external trauma bc anger is ~unnatural~ for women

Anger is one of the only emotions men can express without masculinity being called into question, so psychs don't think anger or aggression in men is extreme or unnatural. They end up thinking the male patient just has trouble regulating their emotions- an indication of ADHD/A

It certainly seems like mental health professionals believe men can be "born this way" (have a neurodevelopmental disability from birth), while women can only be shaped by trauma (develop a mood or personality disorder post-trauma which requires behaviorist intervention)

This theory is admittedly more anecdotal than academic, but I have spoken to a lot of ADHD/autistic people who grew up placed in the "girl" box, & a shocking number of us have to battle through years or decades of misdiagnosis before we can even get screened for ADHD/autism

There are a lot of reasons #ADHD & #autistic women get misdiagnosed w bipolar (BD) or borderline (BPD), but I believe a large part of it is bc mental health professionals don't see women as people who can simply exist, & that our existence can include anger, irritability, & rage

@iaintquiet @AutSciPerson Psychs often don't have time/inclination to go beyond questionnaires & examine these crucial differences, so all too often they use gender/race/income stereotypes to assign a diagnosis to a patient presenting with these overlapping symptoms, instead of doing additional screening

@iaintquiet @AutSciPerson Yeah one of the tough things is that there are so many overlapping symptoms, things that look the same but have different triggers, durations, patterns. My pacing looks like anxiety, but I don't feel anxiety, its more like my brain just doesn't want to work unless I'm moving

Two kids can have the same symptoms, same behaviors, many of the same struggles, but one is in the "boy" box & one is in the "girl" box, so they get different diagnoses. My brother & male cousins were dxed ADHD as kids. I got misdxed & had to figure out ADHD/A on my own in my 30s

I think my bipolar & anxiety misdiagnoses came from doctors viewing my ADHD & autistic behavior through the "girl" filter. Aggression is seen as ~normal~ in boys, so they can be ADHD/A & angry. Aggression is ~not normal~ for girls, so our anger must be a mood/personality disorder

Or I should say our own queerness/transness/nonconformity becomes apparent to us earlier? I didn't mean to say that we are queer/trans/nc just because of our neurodivergence, but rather we are constantly made aware of not fitting into the gender box & thus have to examine the box

I think so many ADHD/autistic ppl are queer/trans in part bc we have to interrogate our relationship w assigned gender early & often. My ADHD/A behavior is often considered "masculine." That left kid me struggling w my own sense of gender while trying to build a mask from scratch

I'm a cis woman. I'm hyperactive, I'm loud & very opinionated, I come off as ~aggressive~ for a woman. I'm not flexible, I'm pedantic, I'm a total klutz w bad posture. When I started consciously bumping up against ~sugar & spice & everything nice~ my distress intensified

It's like the environment around you punches you back into your "correct" gender box at these points in life & it can stagger us. ADHD/A ppl can have an intense relationship w gender- we end up fervently rejecting norms or desperately trying to adhere to them to avoid punishment

My external struggle started in first grade, when I suddenly had to sit all day, be quiet, do tasks. That's when I started getting moved & disciplined, & became vaguely aware of the different standard for boys. The internal, emotional dysregulation struggle began around puberty

Don't wanna pull them into this thread without permission, but someone who QTed sparked something I hadn't thought of before: when we develop from a less-gendered toddler into a kid w a gender expectation attached to us, many of us struggle more- both internally & externally

@AnnieOddly I (kinda) have a similar experience? My first 6-7 years my mom was vaguely Christian, then she started getting more into her Pentecostal church & started holding me tighter to gender roles. Between that & punishment at school, increased awareness of my gender led to more distress

Energy & frenetic movement are so heavily pathologized in women & in BIPoC. And the things we do to manage our excess energy/input & discomfort are heavily pathologized too. I rocked because I wasn't allowed to run wild, & that was used as evidence of anxiety & bipolar disorder

it's particularly infuriating to remember all the times I said "but I pace/rock/sway all the time, regardless of my emotional state. I don't think it's an anxiety thing" and I just got bulldozed every time. They ate away at my own base of knowledge about my ADHD/A body & brain

There are consequences for building the entire research, treatment, & public awareness scaffolding around how middle class white cis boys experience ADHD/autism. Those of us who don't fit that niche can end up spinning out, alone, desperate, knowing something isn't right

As a kid I'd cover my legs in icy hot & wrap them as tightly as I could in ace bandages. Thats what I had to do to relax my legs enough to eventually fall asleep. I knew what I needed. Pressure helped, but instead I was given breathing exercises, or not given any advice at all

Being told that my hyperactivity & sensory issues were anxiety blocked me off from effective treatment, got me misdiagnosed, but most importantly it kept me from knowledge that could've helped me plan for under/overstimulation & significantly lessened my discomfort

I pace, rock, sway, tap, skin-pick, and so on because it feels right. It's what my body does when I'm not using all my mental energy forcing it into agonizing quiet & stillness. It helps when cold or heat or noise or texture puts all the nerves in my body on red alert. It's me.

I didn't say "as if driven by a motor." But since I was a kid I've been talking about how my body feels like a rubber band pulled too tight, an overwound guitar string, a kettle w the vent blocked. It's the same principle as the motor analogy- so much energy it is overwhelming

Even if externally we can cover up the agitation & discomfort, we talk about these issues when we seek help & we get inaccurate labels & ineffective (or harmful) tx bc there's no acknowledgement of how hyperactivity can look outside of cis boys (esp combined w sensory issues)

For a lot of people who grew up w the "girl" label our social acceptance & ability to just exist without punishment depends on throwing every resource into keeping still & quiet, going as far as to dissociate (daydream/ruminate) to escape the constant body discomfort of stillness

Its a "boys will be boys" concept of hyperactivity- that hyperactivity is when little white boys are too loud/rambunctious. As a hyperactive girl, I did not get away w the kind of hyperactivity my male ADHD cousins did. We get told "girls are more mature" practically from birth

I keep thinking about that insight someone had on one of my threads- that the accepted analogy for hyperactivity is "as if driven by a motor-" a phrase many AFAB people wouldn't reach for bc we don't tend to get motorized toys & often aren't encouraged to learn how motors work

Before I was diagnosed w #ADHD & figured out my autism, I'd bring up my pacing, rocking, swaying, skin-picking, tapping, & Drs always told me it was anxiety. I thought of myself as an extremely anxious person, but outside of specific contexts anxiety isn't much of an issue for me

To emphasize my point, here are some ways that ADHD & bipolar can present similarly, & how to distinguish between the two (tho some research suggests #2 may be incorrect as ADHDers can have chronic, debilitating symptoms). This list is about how to distinguish bipolar from ADHD: https://t.co/L4GrEnV6oC

The symptom itself might be legitimate (I don't feel comfortable making that judgement), but it *also* functions as an effective "shut the fuck up" button for psychs who don't lack time or inclination to screen for both, or who consider ~certain people~ less worthy of ADHD dx/tx

This unfortunate (and preventable) scourge of misdiagnosis presents problems. If someone was diagnosed with BD as a young person, but believe that they actually have ADHD and/or autism, they're likely to be dismissed when bringing it up. Rejecting dx/tx is a BD symptom, after all

The callous way people with bipolar are treated in mental healthcare, in media, in society is unacceptable. Full stop. I am not arguing that ADHDers should be exempt from the way BDers are treated. I am arguing that BDers- including misdxed ADHDers- should not be treated poorly

I have been treated as a Bipolar person since I was 18, so I do feel entitled to comment on how people w BD are treated within mental healthcare, but I do not feel comfortable discussing whether the quitting/refusing symptom itself is valid bc I do not believe I am bipolar

quitting treatment or refusing to accept a BD diagnosis indicates two things to me: that treatment is often so poor, so abusive, & the social stigma so high that BDers are desperate to distance themselves from it, & that misdxed ADHDers have little chance at correcting the error

In the 90s boys were 9x more likely than girls to be diagnosed ADHD. As adults, men are only 2 to 3x more likely to be dxed ADHD. Those ADHDers who didn't get diagnosed due to gender bias still had symptoms, and (ancedotally) many seem to have been misdxed w BD or BPD

If bipolar is suspected, ADHD screening should be done. The patient should be thoroughly interviewed. When I was diagnosed with ADHD I did five hours of testing. Bipolar testing should be equally rigorous, especially considering the way BDers are often written off & denied care

But also, its very easy to mistake ADHD/autism for bipolar, and vice versa, especially when you aren't screening for both (which often isn't done but absolutely should be). There are overlapping symptoms, but even these function differently, & in ways questionnaires can't clarify

As someone w a BD diagnosis (which I believe to be misdxed ADHD & autism), I think it's only natural for BDers to reject diagnosis/treatment, because they're treated like garbage in most mental health care. They're regarded as liars, manipulators, "addicts." They are denied care.

I've been describing the discomfort & tension in my body as an "overwound guitar string" or a "kettle with the vent blocked" since I was 14. But the approved analogy for hyperactivity is "as if driven by a motor," so even though they're all excess energy, mine is called anxiety

I've been telling psychs about my rocking, swaying, walking back & forth daydreaming or ruminating, since I was 14. These things have always been attributed to anxiety, no matter how many times I've insisted that I do these things constantly & rarely feel anxious while doing so

the worst part is that ADHD/A ppl spend yrs bringing up issues that should- in a rational, ethical world- be clear indications of hyperactivity, sensory issues, inattention, repetitive behaviors, but are dismissed. These vital clues get misattributed to anxiety/depression/trauma

So we're talking about struggling our entire lives, decades, all because the people who were supposed to help us didn't bother to figure out what kind of emotional lability condition we had & just went with whatever sounded close enough. It's breathtakingly cruel. It's despicable

Bipolar meds will not work for ADHD/autism. Borderline treatment will not work for ADHD/autism. In fact, depending on the meds (SSRIs especially) it can drastically worsen our symptoms. So we're too poor to ~deserve~ treatment, which ensures we stay poor & struggle indefinitely

Based on my experience & experiences of countless other poor & marginalized ppl, it seems like psychs diagnose based on type, not on individual symptoms. For ADHD, this seems to be bc the first line treatment is a controlled substance & us dirty poors can't be trusted w ~drugs~

I should also say that the acceptability of ADHD & autism is based on the patient's socioeconomic status & their ability to "pass" as neurotypical or be productive in ways that can be monetized. I think this is part of why poor, marginalized, & high support folks get locked out

I never want my posts about how easily psychs mistake ADHD/autism for bipolar or borderline to be interpreted as some sort of hierarchy with neurodevelopmental disabilities at the top, mood & personality disorders at the bottom. NO PATIENT SHOULD BE DISMISSED OR ABUSED. Period.

And we should be very fucking loud about the fact that ADHD & autism are paywalled diagnoses given a veneer of acceptability due to who tends to get these diagnoses- wealthy white people. While ppl w BD or BPD dx tend to be poor, marginalized, & routinely abused by doctors for it

I firmly believe that any psych who is diagnosing bipolar or borderline within a session or two & is not screening for ADHD & autism before diagnosis, is committing malpractice, harming patients, and likely choosing their bias over their ethical obligations

The frustrating thing is that it isn't particularly difficult to distinguish ADHD/autism (<-these two can be tricky to tell apart sometimes) from bipolar or borderline. There are commonalities, but also distinct features of each- you just have to be looking at the whole patient

This makes it easy for psychs to misdiagnose patients that they have some sort of implicit (or explicit) bias towards- like poor ppl, women, BIPoC. I am not being hyperbolic when I say that the practice of dxing BD & BPD based solely on lability is harming & killing ADHD/A people

It actually took quite a bit of reading to find out that emotional dysregulation was an ADHD symptom at all, because despite 70% of ADHD adults & 80% of ADHD kids experiencing emotional lability, it is not in the DSM criteria for ADHD and is rarely discussed as an ADHD symptom

Emotional lability is the term used by mental health professionals to describe this, but it's also the term used for emotional fluctuations in borderline personality disorder & bipolar disorder, despite the fact that they often function differently than lability in ADHD & autism

The interesting thing about #ADHD/#autism emotional dysregulation is that you have this huge, extreme emotional response, but it burns so hot it isn't sustainable. So a few minutes or a few hours later you're emotionally fine, maybe great even, but physically & mentally exhausted

None of this is a new conversation, but I still feel a sting of shame when my kid is happily watching TV & I'm on my phone, like I've broken parenting law. But talking to her while we are occupied w screens, not being irritated & uncomfortable, is better than just being irritated

Like a lot of ADHDers I have an auditory processing delay. I have poor processing speed and working memory. I have sensory issues, repetitive movements ease discomfort but can cause pain. My phone allows me to be social. Without it I would've been isolated for the last 10 years

Parenting advice tells us that if your kid watches TV at all their brain will become sawdust. But TV was always a source of comfort and companionship for me, a source of new fixations, a guide to relationships & social behaviors that didn't make sense to me in the real world

Scrolling on a phone is also less physically painful than many other stims can be. I would probably be a lot more comfortable in social interactions if I allowed myself to scroll instead of just squirming in my uncomfortable skin, irritated, bc my RSD alarm never turns off

Society generally views things like phone/computer usage (for non-work reasons) as bad, lazy, childish, whatever. As unproductive. Which sucks, bc so many neurodivergent ppl learn about ourselves, communicate & find community through these tools, & we get constant shame for it

@paarsec It's exhausting. I can't infer why someone is mad, but I can tell they are, so my brain just autocompletes to "they're mad at you bc you fucked up again," then I get annoyed or angry bc I have no idea what I did. When you're constantly in trouble you just learn to expect it

Maybe that's a combined ADHD & autism thing? A combination of trying to survive and trying to manage rejection sensitive dysphoria. When masking you kinda have to assume that any negative feeling around you is because of you, bc you won't be able to tell (and often it is you)

Seems like a lot of people who mask just kinda end up adapting to their environment & company by default, fitting themselves in to minimize rejection, embarrassment, criticism, bc we've gotten so much of it by the time we hit adulthood & are desperate to prevent any more of it

If I'm in a relaxed, low pressure environment w ppl I know & am comfortable with, my mood is good. But I crumble under tension. I think in part bc I'm so used to being In Trouble that when someone is angry around me I think they're angry at me? Like "I guess I fucked up again" 🤷‍♀️

This is another "#ADHD, #autism, or both" question, but it can be physically (& emotionally) painful to be in emotionally heavy, tense, or unwelcoming environments/situations. I soak it up like a sponge, & it turns into anger inside me (maybe bc anger triggers adrenaline? Idk)

ADHDers have a significantly higher risk of Alzheimer's. All 4 of my grandma's grandkids have ADHD. My great grandma had severe Alzheimer's before she passed. I can't get treatment for my ADHD, can't work, live in poverty. I'm terrified about what will happen to me in the future

Repeating the same noises, words, or phrases over and over, known as echolalia. It's considered more common in autism, but some ADHDers do it too. I find myself getting stuck on a word or noise & I can't stop saying it, always try to find ways to use it, or its on loop in my head

CW: eating disorder
.
.
Picky eating & disordered eating- It's often dismissed as attention-seeking, or attributed to anxiety or depression, but #ADHD-ers & #autistic ppl are more likely to have eating disorders. For me, 300-600 calories a day & dropping weight became a fixation

Skin picking, tapping, nail biting, knuckle-cracking, playing with my hair- this is a common way for hyperactivity to manifest in afab ADHDers bc we have less latitude to run, jump, be loud & rambunctious. "Boys will be boys," but growing up we hear "girls mature more quickly"

Rocking and swaying- this is another one that was always dismissed as anxiety, but it's not an anxiety thing- it's an all the time thing. I do it because I *have* to move, bc there's too much energy inside of me. It helps w sensory distress, hyperactivity, general ND discomfort

"Revving up"- my entire life I've done this thing where I get up & pace back & forth while daydreaming or ruminating. I do it when my body feels bad, or when I'm trying to jumpstart my brain & focus. I was told it was anxiety. It made other people anxious, not me. It feels good

I'm really frustrated because I had a clear idea of what I wanted this thread to be when I started it, but then all my thoughts scattered to the wind and now I'm just rambling

Another autistic person may have zero points in charisma, like they're all in science or strength or something. An allistic looks at our different builds and thinks "oh, clearly they are playing two different games!" We are playing the same game, the same system, just differently

Going with the RPG analogy, it's like I dumped my stat points into charisma (language/social skills), and whatever was left went to intelligence. I have almost no practical skills to keep me alive, so the game is a constant struggle despite having better conversation options

The allistic stereotype of #autism is that it's like a first person video game w a preset character. But autistic ppl know it's more like an RPG, with a variety of traits that can be distributed differently, resulting in radically different builds that are part of the same system

there's rarely any examination of what led to the ~bad behavior~, what it feels like to have a sensory meltdown, how painful and disorienting and scary it can be. It's just the parent character stressing out, apologizing like "sorry, he's autistic, he just loses it sometimes" 🤷‍♂️

I got sidetracked with fictional representations of autism, but that's what people who don't know (or don't realize that they know/are) an autistic person will think of. Fiction leans heavily into the trope of the "low-functioning" autistic behaving badly & needing to be managed

It's been a while since I watched Parenthood, but Max Braverman is the most prominent example of an autistic character I can think of, and mostly fits that stereotype of what autism is. That stereotype made me think I wasn't autistic, bc I didn't see myself in those characters

of course you can be autistic w some of these traits, but public perception of autism has been shaped not by autistic people, but by parents of autistic children- and it shows. The writing of autistic characters often centers around the hurt or inconvenience they cause allistics

Thinking back on the (godawful) autism stereotypes in media gave me the impression that autistic people are:
White
Male
Either can't express or can't feel love
Do not care about or consider the needs of other people
Are good at math

Growing up poor you learn quickly how precarious your life is, how the bottom can drop out. That dread lives inside you, snarled & waiting like an Old God. Keeping it at bay requires effort, leaving you less energy to manage lability, frustration, organization, sensory issues

...I was 3 when our electricity got shut off & we moved into my grandma's basement. I was 11 when we had my dad's first intervention. I got dxed w bipolar the same year my dad left & my home got foreclosed. My emotional lability looks extreme in comparison bc I had more stressors

I think this is part of why so many poor & marginalized ADHDers/autistics end up misdxed w bipolar or borderline. If you're a comfortably middle class kid you don't have the same stress as a poor kid, you benefit from early dx/tx & have more energy to devote to self-regulation...

A person who has always been comfortably middle class, who has never had to put off crucial dental care for years bc they need to pay rent & buy food, will not understand how something like constant throbbing pain in your jaw negatively contributes to mood & emotional regulation

Sorry, but as a dirty poor, "self-care" is about as useful to me as those "how I bought a house at 21 years old by skipping Starbucks (and 300k from mommy & daddy)" articles. No amount of self care gets me dental coverage before my teeth rot out bc I can't afford a root canal

Beyond general cluelessness & apathy, a lot of psychs believe that they can't change the systemic issues & shouldn't discuss things they can't fix. But dismissing the impact our material conditions have on our ability to "self-care" or whatever only alienates the most vulnerable

It's really hard to make progress on your mental health when you're unhoused, struggling to buy food or pay rent, uninsured or can't afford to use your insurance, etc. Behaviorism assumes you can condition your way out of being poor in a system you have no individual power within

Behaviorism is the neoliberalism of mental health. That's like 75% a joke, but it's the same kind of individualistic bootstraps bullshit which insists that you just need to work hard & believe in yourself. Shhh, don't bring up material conditions which you are powerless to change

This is part of why I find behaviorism so vile too, bc it assumes everyone has equal (comfortably middle class) resources & simply need to condition themselves to think/do "good" things instead of "bad" things. I exist in precarity & poverty- expecting the worst is how we survive https://t.co/cep3nZlqLr

@red_feminist It's so frustrating. I'm sure some of them try & mean well, but they can't conceive of not having a safety net, not having any security or consistency, the constant stress of being poor, so their attempts to condition you to have better thoughts & habits assume you have resources

I'm sure you'll be surprised to hear that they opened every appointment by saying "we don't prescribe controlled substances." Very normal to tell patients that regardless of their medical needs they will only get what they're allowed to have. Really upfront wallet biopsy shit

The place I used to go provided mental health services for the county jail & local prison, so sometimes you'd come in for an appointment & see a guy in literal fucking chains being guarded by a dude with a gun. The providers saw everyone as a ~criminal~ & treated us like it

So low income mental health is run by ppl w comfortable upbringings, comfortable lives, ppl who are young, inexperienced & just starting their careers, older & too bad to get a better job, or (and this seems the most common) sadists who enjoy exercising power over vulnerable ppl

Also therapists are people who could afford to finish school, are much more likely to have grown up at least middle class, are currently prolly middle class, & have no idea what poverty is like. Poor ppl who put themselves through school can't afford to stay in low income care

Mad TV had a sketch with Bob Newhart once, and he was playing his shrink character from his eponymous show, but instead of doing shrink shit he just grabbed the patient by the shoulders and yelled "STOP IT!!" - That's pretty much what low income mental healthcare is like

I think therapy can be useful for some people or for certain situations. Talk therapy can be helpful for working through trauma, I've heard some folks with BPD praise CBT & DBT, and that's very good & cool if you can afford a decent practitioner

Therapy seems to presume that there is some kind of equilibrium, & if I just work hard enough my life could be something beyond stress & chaos, but even if I were the most mentally-well fucker on Earth poverty is still gonna wreck my shit, so I struggle to see the point

I really struggle to comfort people when they're grieving because I can't dole out platitudes, they seem unbelievably rude & harmful, so I just freeze up & go silent because I know I can't change anything for them, can't take their pain away. So platitudes are not helpful for me

I guess if you have resources it might be beneficial to pressure you to change how you allocate those resources, but I'm not eating like shit because I like it- my car is broken down and the only store we can walk to is a Dollar Tree that doesn't have any fresh fruits or veggies

I've only had a little bit of low income therapy, maybe rich people get something more substantial, but in my experience therapy has been like "have you considered not being neurodivergent? Like just stop doing the bad things and do more good things and you will feel better"

This is part of why therapy is meh for me- my day to day stress, anxiety, & depression are caused by poverty & uncertainty, & exacerbated by my untreated ADHD (also thanks to capitalism & sexism), so therapy often comes off as useless platitudes or straight up victim-blaming https://t.co/zZacD41PzI

Drs on TV tirelessly slog to solve medical mysteries for vulnerable patients, but in real life if you have any symptom that isn't textbook, or give the wrong ~vibe~, Drs think they're Batman foiling a nefarious plot. Like sure buddy, you're the Dark Knight of gaslighting women

I think this is part of why #ADHD-ers are such creative problem-solvers, because our solutions aren't necessarily coming from the strictly rational part of the brain, they can be emotional or impulsive in a way that happens to uniquely fit the problem

I'm not a computer-knower, but RAM is how your computer does what its currently doing, like running programs or playing games. It's kinda the computer's working memory & processing speed, which many ADHDers struggle with. Memory would be how much info you can store for later use

The logical, rational, planning, problem-solving, organizational part of the #ADHD brain has a ton of processing capacity, but it boots up slowly, lags behind the emotional & impulsive part of the brain, & errors out if overloaded. We're got bottomless memory, but very little RAM

Getting things done is tough w #ADHD because the part of the brain that thinks "I need to do that" has a weak signal to the part of the brain that actually *does* things. You need to do something, try to prioritize doing it, but it gets moved to the back of the task queue somehow

I can't emphasize enough how much time the simple, basic, staying-alive shit takes for me. If it's a new or personally interesting task I can often go more quickly than average. If its not new or interesting it's like my body/brain are trying to escape molasses. Walking can help

It feels like my brain doesn't boot up unless I take my hyperactivity for a walk. When I write I'm usually walking. I feel like I can't think unless I move, so any task I can't walk while doing takes forever, bc I'm constantly taking breaks to walk & think, & losing track of time

Transitions between tasks are where I do a lot of "revving up." I think #ADHD-ers do this many ways, but for me I walk back & forth for minutes (or hours), just thinking, daydreaming, ruminating. Like the brain airport is too busy & flights/tasks are in a holding pattern

Trying to drag yourself into doing something you aren't interested in, something tedious or boring or just not new and/or interesting, it's a real fucking struggle. My legs feel heavy. Something inside me feels the way a toddler looks when they're about to have a tantrum

When I was working, I'd be doing great when we were busy. I was always on drive-thru, bc I guess a lot of people struggle w that multitasking, but as long as I kept having things to do I was great. If we got slammed I might melt down spectacularly. If too slow my body would rebel

This was a huge issue for me in school. Our classes were like 45-50 minutes, and often unbearable. Sometimes I'd be grateful to get sent out into the hall, bc I could stand & sway, splay out on the floor, keep moving. Stuck in the classroom I'd talk or daydream & get in trouble

Neurodivergence requires constant weighing & juggling of what you're naturally inclined to do vs what you're expected to do. Without something to speed the day up I'm more irritable. I have more time w my kid, but its often less *quality* time bc I'm bored & in sensory overload

I've been hyperfocusing on Borderlands 2. Its that hyperfocus where you get sullen & irritated when you have to do anything else, which is not great when you have a toddler or need to, y'know, live. My day to day life is painfully slow & boring, running & gunning makes it fly by

NarxCare is the initial gatekeeper for ADHD, anxiety, or pain meds, essentially deciding whether you are the ~type~ of person who "deserves" care. The restrictions we see on controlled substances are the next layer of gatekeeping: making it inaccessible to ppl without resources

NarxCare claims that it's just supposed to be a tool that doctors can use to evaluate risk of substance use disorder or overdose in patients, and that doctors still have the final word on diagnosis & treatment. But doctors get arrested & indicted for defying the algorithm, so 🤷‍♀️

Before a doctor can prescribe to you they must check this Overdose Risk Score- a score which is decontextualized data + stereotypes = risk

"But it's a machine! It can't have bias!"- its an algorithm programmed by people who live in a demonstrably unequal society. It has bias.

If you're poor &/or have certain comorbidities you have more stress, more worry. The emotional dysregulation of ADHD amplifies these negative experiences & stressors, and can lead to drug use to numb yourself or suicide attempts- both of which make you too "high risk" for care

My anxiety in my day to day life is pretty low & almost always connected to something I've procrastinated because I'm #ADHD. I get a bit of anxiety when I'm out & about, especially when I have to focus on something. But my anxiety in a Drs office is sky-fucking-high, like... https://t.co/WoLRhqoknh

The Dr's office is an intersection of the personal & systemic. My treatment is poor bc I'm a poor woman, my RSD & emotional lability take off, I get angry about how irrational & counterproductive our healthcare system & drug laws are. I feel crushed by 10+ years of medical trauma

I ruminate about other things, social situations that go poorly, but I get STUCK on injustices, abuses, a system that creates & maintains classes of "lesser" ppl who exist to generate profit through labor or incarceration & preferably die before they can collect Social Security

I think I ruminate about my past mistreatment by Drs in part because I have these inflexible ethical positions about how people in positions of trust and authority should behave. When a Dr dismisses me, or gets hostile when I start crying, it feels like a rejection & a violation

It's difficult to find the borders between my #ADHD & #autism, but I think part of why I react so badly to being dismissed by Drs is bc the imagined psych believes me more often than not. When reality is the total opposite of what I "planned" (daydreamed) I don't handle it well

autism may come into play w this too, a lot of autistic ppl survive a NT world by constantly running scenarios in our heads, processing events, imagining sequences of events & their potential consequences, rehearsing interactions (likely also my response to poor processing speed)

I define daydreaming as imagining good scenarios, & rumination as imagining bad scenarios. So usually it's just my own non-stop internal dialogue, but sometimes the imagined psych believes me & helps me, & sometimes they treat me badly. It's like Schrodinger's train of thought

Daydreaming & rumination used to be distinct, but in recent years the lines have blurred. My mental hyperactivity is often stuck thinking about ADHD & autism, & it's like my brain uses a framing device for that: a constant internal dialogue w a vaguely-imagined hypothetical psych

#ADHD daydreaming happens when the external world doesn't provide enough stimulation to hold attention. For me, it can also happen during sensory distress. But I also think it may be part of how ADHDers conceptualize The Future- a future we struggle to plan for in the present

I can daydream about it, but I have a very limited ability to plan for the long term. The future has always existed in a daydream/fantasy space for me. But now I've lived, a lot of it has been bad, & now my mental hyperactivity often gets stuck processing those bad experiences

So a psych might associate daydreaming with inattentive ADHD in children perceived as girls (if they bother to ask about it), but they make the assumption that the character of ADHD daydreaming never changes, even as the undiagnosed/untreated adult continues to struggle & suffer

professional knowledge about #ADHD/autistic daydreaming & rumination is limited by the same thing other #ADHDautism symptoms are: research & diagnostic criteria are shaped by how ADHD & #autism present in upper middle class white cis kids (usually boys) diagnosed in childhood

Its like my ADHD tries to set up a fun fantasy so I can escape my boring reality, but my autism understands *why* this is my reality, all the systemic factors that lead to misdiagnosis & continued struggle. Factors that very likely won't improve, making daydreams less fulfilling

I dunno what happens in anyone else's head, perhaps my experience is more typical for ADHD/autistic ppl than either condition on their own. But my brain has to constantly be doing something- breaking something down, telling a story, fantasies, speeches, arguments, it's always on

Going into my 30s w undiagnosed #ADHDautism, I still had daydreams, but I also had rumination. I have medical trauma I can't get past bc its still happening, I struggled through school, work, relationships. Mental hyperactivity pursues pain & suffering just as eagerly as fantasy

We talk about daydreaming with inattentive #ADHD, but we don't talk about rumination. As a kid it was all daydreams. Cool, fun stuff like I'm a rock star, I'm an actress, I'm a... war correspondent? (I was a weird kid). It was an entertaining escape from an unstimulating world

@recombobulating It happened a lot w teachers too. I'd get in trouble, start crying bc I felt rejected/humiliated/criticized, & they'd get hostile w me bc they assumed I was trying to cry my way out of trouble. Clearly anyone who thinks like that isn't a crier, bc it never gets you out of trouble

@recombobulating Same. It's why I have high anxiety or panic attacks when I go to the Dr. When I was seeking care for chronic pain Drs told me it was psychosomatic. When they dismissed me I would feel intensely rejected & judged, start crying, & be tacitly accused of manipulation & "drug-seeking"

Which is especially cruel, bc undiagnosed #ADHD-ers don't know that their ADHD symptoms are symptoms. Most of us have been told we're messy, lazy, careless, selfish, that we have these moral failures instead of a specific neurotype. So you only talk about lability & get misdxed

The one I guess positive thing I can say is that these heightened emotional states are usually brief, generally lasting minutes or hours, instead of days/weeks/months. But they are spectacularly intense- which can lead to psychs misdiagnosing an ADHDer as bipolar or borderline

Especially when you're crunched for time, this just gets more & more frustrating. I'm autistic as well, & I really struggle with transitioning from doing one thing to doing another. This usually leads to me either pep-talking or verbally abusing myself (or both) out loud

Leaving the house can be exhausting- getting dressed, remembering to grab everything I need, finding things I need (yikes), planning what I need to do. My body stops cooperating, like I'm doing a Buster Keaton physical comedy bit knocking shit over & stumbling (hello dyspraxia!)

I blow up, I melt down, I shut down. 70% of adults with ADHD have emotional lability. Our limbic system reacts to something before our prefrontal cortex- with its poor processing speed- can tell us to chill out. I also love in a huge way. Feel joy (and sorrow) in a huge way

And that's kinda upsetting, bc until you know about your ADHD & start recognizing all the other frustrations you were able to keep in check that day, it really feels like you're just an asshole who gets ragey for no real reason at all, and you wonder what kind of person you are

Don't get me wrong there are single small events that can put me on the express train to Rage Town (like my wireless mouse not working hahaha oh god it gets bad), but usually it's bottling these little frustrations, trying not to show them, until I'm so pissed off I can't breathe

The thing about #ADHD frustration tolerance is that it initially seems like you're losing your shit over one small, ostensibly insignificant thing. But for me, it's usually stacking minor frustration upon minor frustration endlessly until the stack collapses (or explodes)

I don't know if "gendertyping" is a word, but I'm gonna start using it to describe the gendered stereotypes about ADHD & autism, bc they are deeply harmful and result in so many struggling kids not getting the support they need, struggling into adulthood as their lives implode

This is embarassing to talk about, but I've always overshared on the internet so... More importantly, there's a common misconception that women w #ADHD are always inattentive but manage to remain good students. I'm combined, present largely hyperactive, & floundered

So yeah, that's how undiagnosed #ADHD, unsupported #autism, and just general apathy I guess, can destroy a kid's future & keep on destroying them. To be fair to my mom I was def the least of her worries at that point- my brother & father had much more volatile, obvious issues

My mom went w a fundie Christian homeschool. It was in physical workbooks that had to be graded by my mom & maybe sent in. My mom nagged me a few times about the work the first few months, but then we both just kinda... forgot about it? Put it off? I accidentally dropped out

The first week of what would've been 11th grade I was told I was being left back to repeat 10th grade again. I was humiliated, didn't want to live, spent a lot of time verbally abusing myself for it. A friend was doing online homeschool, so I begged my mom to let me do homeschool

I only made it to 10th grade bc I went to summer school. Things didn't improve. School was a place I went. In daydreams my future was clear and bright, but in reality I couldn't plan for a future, couldn't stick to a schedule, couldn't listen long enough to hear the assignment

Daydreaming brought me joy. Earbuds had just become a thing, and I had big curly hair, so I'd put a bud in one ear during class. Suddenly class didn't feel like it lasted an eternity. I was squirming less, wasn't getting kicked out of class. But I couldn't make myself do homework

A school counselor pressured my mom to get me help. We went to a low income clinic, I don't think I ever saw the same provider twice. They only asked about my moods, not the other 100 symptoms I didn't know about. I was a poor teenage girl- of course I was diagnosed w depression

CW: suicide
.
.
By 9th grade I was deeply depressed. We don't talk about it enough, but 1 in 4 ADHD women attempt suicide. Autistic women are twice as likely to attempt suicide as autistic men. Girls/women who are both ADHD & autistic are at particularly high risk https://t.co/caYyqDQW02

I was too embarrassed to ask for help. I'd steal my report card out of the mailbox, hide it, & wait for my mom to not notice. I couldn't ask for help bc I didn't know how to explain that I knew the subjects (except math), I just couldn't make myself do homework. It was boring.

The issues with talking and moving in class persisted. I kept spending weeks sitting in the hallway (where I could sit on the floor, move around, & was 10x more comfortable). I'd zone out daydreaming in class, not even hear the assignment, go home & watch soap operas instead

So I went from one B at the end of 5th grade, to mostly Cs, Ds, and Fs in my first semester of 6th grade. It was all down to homework. I was still mostly able to do class work, I would eagerly do projects I could be creative with, and I kept testing my way into the next grade

I got my first B at the end of 5th grade (which, like most grades, had exiled me to the hall for a substantial period of time for talking in class). That's when I had my first suicidal thought. I felt humiliated, and rejection sensitive dysphoria kicked in HARD

I always got in trouble for talking in class, but up until 5th grade I had good grades. In 5th grade we started getting more homework. Nobody was staying on me about homework, & I couldn't force myself to do it. I often wonder what would've happened if my #ADHD had been treated

Lets say a neurotypical person goes to bed at 11pm & wakes at 7am. ADHDers trying to fit into that societal rhythm are roughly like a NT person forcing themselves to go to sleep at 7pm & wake at 3am every day. It's possible, but it's not the default & can be very difficult on you

Oh wait one more interesting bit of sleep info: up to 75% of ADHDers have Delayed Circadian Rhythm Phase. Circadian rhythm is how your body regulates your wake-sleep cycle, but for ADHDers our schedule is later than typical- our bodies want to sleep at 12am-3am & wake at 10-11am

feels like NTs do things like clean, bathe, brush their teeth, change their clothes by habit, without having to constantly think about it & force themselves into it. But things I'm not *interested* in often don't even occur to me, and require more time & effort than is typical

My emotional lability & sensory sensitivities have been bad this week (the week before my period- which can significantly exacerbate ADHD symptoms in afab people). I've been staying up til 2-3am (I get up at 6) playing Borderlands 2 to cope with the stress

So I'm tired, my frustration tolerance is shattered, the emotional center of the brain takes off while the logical part lags behind. For me, this extra distress makes me crave more time to dedicate to my latest New Interesting Thing, so I sleep less. Insomnia & ADHD intensify e/o

Sleep deprivation makes virtually every ADHD symptom worse. The fatigue clashes with the hyperactivity & sensory sensitivity, so your body always feels wrong. You're a second away from meltdown on a good day, but being tired obliterates your frustration tolerance

one thing we don't talk about enough is that people w #ADHD, especially late-diagnosed/untreated ADHDers, have chronic sleep deprivation. Even at 6y/o I'd pretend to be sleepy, then play or read in my bed for hours. As an adult I still put my interests before my need for sleep

ADHD Emotional lability isn't irrational. What we feel doesn't come out of nowhere, it has a tangible root. Our emotions are typical for the circumstance- they're just turned up to 11 and spilling out of us. Our limbic system takes off before our prefrontal cortex can catch up

My whole life, every bit of it I can remember, I have been uncomfortable and restless. "Relaxing" for me always includes sitting cross-legged & rocking back and forth. I could only pump milk for my kid by zoning out on my phone & getting under the weighted blanket when I finished

I told my mom that my legs hurt, because I was probably five or six and didn't know "uncomfortable" or "restless," so I said it was pain. The doctor said it was growing pains, so I just kept doing it until I was 14 or 15 and started piling tons of blankets on top of me at night

As a kid my restlessness & sensory issues were so bad (esp at night) that I regularly covered my legs in icy hot & wrapped them as tightly as I could in ace bandages. My toes were nearly purple in the morning. That's what it took to ease the Bad Body Feels

@GrudzienBarbara @TaraMorrigan In the 90s boys were 9x more likely to be diagnosed with ADHD than girls were. But as adults, men are only 2-3x more likely to be diagnosed than women. That means there's a whole lost generation of women w ADHD who have been misdiagnosed, dismissed, & now have to fight for care

Unfortunately a lot of Drs slap "depression" on any complaint- mental or physical- that a woman has. Anxiety is used to cover any gaps between symptoms the patient describes & the final diagnosis. I kept not fitting depression or anxiety, so they got out the bipolar stamp too

I think it's also tough for people who don't fit neatly within the prescribed set of ADHD behaviors associated w their perceived gender. Like the majority of ADHDers, I have combined presentation, but present on the hyperactive side. My late-dxed cis male partner is inattentive

It took me so long to separate sensory distress or shutdown from panic attacks. They are very different experiences, but both were rolled into "anxiety." I couldn't actually take steps to help myself better manage my (far more frequent) sensory distress bc didn't know it existed

My body constantly feels uncomfortable, but feels slightly better when I rock while sitting cross-legged. Deep breathing exercises don't "fix" that. For 10 yrs I rated my anxiety as very high, bc psychs kept telling me all these disparate non-anxiety symptoms were anxiety

I told them (whatever low income psych I saw for a session or two before they got a better job) that I pace a lot, and pacing has the anxiety connotation. But I also stressed that I'm usually not anxious when I'm pacing. When I'm anxious I lock down. I walk to kick start my brain

I need to "rev up" before (and during) any activity I have to concentrate on, which is basically anything I'm not hyperfocused on in that moment. I walk back & forth daydreaming for an hour or two before I start, & I keep taking breaks to walk. I was told pacing = anxiety

People tell me things & its like I'm supposed to know they mean something different, except I don't have any idea what they expect. I get confused at forms bc each question seems like it could mean several different things. Of course I'm anxious- the world is hostile to ND people

I'm always forgetting important things or leaving them to the last possible second. Even watching a show I enjoy, my partner will make a comment about it & I suddenly realize I have no idea what's happening bc I was thinking "whatever happened to the good taco truck" or something

I'm constantly forgetting things, losing or accidentally destroying things, not paying attention when important information is being explained, I struggle big time with transitions & staying on task. So basically I've been in trouble my whole life. Of course I'm fucking anxious.

Feels like a lot of #ADHD & #autistic women get misdiagnosed w anxiety, or their anxiety is seen as the primary condition, rather than secondary to ADHD/A. Psychs told me my rocking, swaying, skin picking, fidgeting was all anxiety. Prolly bc they couldn't explain it w depression

Nobody ever remembers this show & it bugs me, because I *loved* it. I'm only now realizing how much of my love of dystopian fiction & science fiction came from James Cameron's Dark Angel series. It helped to shape me politically in a big way

There's also an emphasis on surveillance. I don't remember exactly what the political situation was, but it certainly came across as authoritarian, where the military has unbridled money & power to abuse people with. Eyes Only was *thrilling* to me as a 12 y/o

Dark Angel had some potent class politics. Through Logan- the Engels to Max's Marx- we get to see how the rich are living post-EMP, while the people in Max's world are struggling to buy medicine & afford shelter. Cops, landlords, bosses, the ruling class are all on the same side

And I mean the main character is named Max Guevara. Max herself chose the name Guevara. Her primary activity before the series & in season 1 is robbing rich people (only rich people). Max & Cindy get hassled by dirty cops, sleazy landlords, Reaganite bosses, & come out on top

Max, Joshua, & the other Manticore kids feel like a disability narrative. The medical & non-medical trauma is deeply relatable. They were genetically enhanced to be supersoldiers, but they also have seizures & other medical issues bc of it. They were abused, gaslit, & isolated.

it's been awhile since I watched, but I think Dark Angel was pretty progressive, especially for the year 2000. Original Cindy is maybe the first TV lesbian I remember? Normal finds out he's dating a trans woman, still loves her, & gets dumped when she realizes she's a lesbian

Hyperfocus- we can do Thing in a normal amount of time, or sometimes more quickly than most

DREAD- legs are lead, body fighting back, I was born to suffer, I want to fight, takes 4x as long

When CPP advocate for access to opioids instead of demanding more non-opioid therapies (that anyone w enough money can already get), we're accused of "drug-seeking." This assumes the premise & underlying data of the CDC Guidelines were correct. They demonstrably were not.

Stop bleeding patients dry w endless new therapies, stop making them bleed w NSAIDs while pretending they are "safe & effective." Let patients recover from surgery, die of cancer, live w pain without putting the vague, unlikely potential for "abuse" above their actual, real pain

Here's my pitch: treat pain. Stop treating ~certain patients~ as liars, malingerers, & "drug-seekers," and instead promote open, trusting, collaborative relationships with doctors so *if* there's a substance use issue (which is rare with chronic pain) it can be properly addressed

We're in a hell of branded express CBT programs, bizarre surveillance fantasies, codified medical discrimination against poor people, women, & BIPoC, & instead of acknowledging the harm done to poor & marginalized patients, the unaffected are pitching their projects for funding

I read a "wish list" written by a doctor which included daydreaming about a medication dispenser that monitors a patient in their home to make sure they're exercising & meeting other undefined requirements before an opioid is dispensed. Like a dog with an automated food dish.

It feels hopeless. Looking at the surge of overdose deaths & pain patient suicides post-2016, clearly none of what the powers that be were allegedly aiming for was achieved by this policy, but now there's an opioid-sparing industry whose profits are more important than our lives

But for a lot of autistic kids, our bluntness gets us in trouble. Being upfront with our needs or struggles gets us punished. We learn how to "pass" as "normal" under duress, under constant threat. Lying becomes survival, a conditioned response to constant negative feedback

My toddler illustrates a lot of this for me. She says "I want x" or "I need x," & I don't yell at her for being rude/demanding. I know if she's melting down due to sensory stuff or understimulation bc I've had those meltdowns. She advocates for herself bc I don't shut her down

To me, this is the difference between autistic & allistic lying. I lie so I won't be a target, to avoid punishment for things I don't understand, to meet needs I can no longer articulate due to trauma. Lying to hurt or take advantage of a person seems like such a violation to me

At 18 y/o I was friends w an older girl. Her husband told me they had an open relationship. No part of me had even a hint of suspicion that he would lie. He manipulated me into things that made me uncomfortable. I have flashbacks. My lovely friend had no idea (I'm so sorry, S)

Speaking for myself as an autistic person, I am extremely trusting, to the point that it makes things dangerous to me. I generally don't assume people have alterior motives, that they would lie or manipulate me. For me, #ADHDautistim is like being an exposed nerve, an open wound

I've seen several people say it, but trauma is so ubiquitous for autistic (and many undiagnosed/untreated ADHDers) that it's hard to separate the autism from the trauma. Masking is our attempt to make ourselves small, quiet, less of a target in a world we don't understand

And this is all bullshit, to be clear. My partner is a cis man, I'm a cis woman. We have the same range of symptoms. Some of them we express a bit differently based on gender norms we were raised in (not nearly as differently as psychs seem to think), but we're both #ADHDautistic

Inherent in this is the assumption is that women don't feel anger, can't be born w heightened anger, if we're angry it must be bc of some external factor (trauma inflicted on us primarily by men), while men can have these default states where this is just how their brain is wired

Psychs also seem to think that women are singularly defined by trauma (and I guess that men just... don't have trauma bc they don't talk about it?🙄). So for women, trauma is used to say "she was made into this" (personality disorder), while men were *born* like this (ADHDautism)

But instead the diagnostic process seems to be "girl has emotional lability, but it's the wrong kind for her gender so she has a mood or personality disorder" and "boy has the correct emotional lability for his gender, so he has ADHD and/or Autism"

It is highly irresponsible to diagnose a patient w bipolar disorder without screening them for ADHD & autism. Emotional lability duration should be weighed with other factors like frustration, attention, planning, organization, hyperactivity, sensory issues to differentiate the 2

"girls" are punished for anger, but not for other emotions (esp not by social networks), we learn to rely on friends for emotional support, bc we're used to seeking support we seek mental healthcare, generate a "high risk" history, & struggle bc we're misdiagnosed early & often

So with this framework: "boys" have emotional lability, are punished for expressing emotions that aren't anger, learn to rely on romantic partners for emotional support, don't ask for help, if they make it to adulthood without ADHD/autism diagnosis its relatively easy to get dxed

(But if anyone has an issue with the terminology I'm using please let me know, I'm more than happy to talk about ways I can illustrate the "perceived gender" problem more concisely and acceptably)

(this is tough bc so much of this relies on gender roles & expectations, misogyny, which is based not on who you are, but how you're perceived. Since drs are often transphobic assbags, they perceive trans ppl as their assigned sex, so talking about "men" vs "women" is useful)

Drs detect heightened emotions when "women" talk abt the variety of their heightened emotional response, & conclude "girl has bipolar" without inquiring about sensory issues, attention, planning, organization, the things that would help distinguish between bipolar & ADHD lability

I have HUGE, immediate heightened emotional responses. But, crucially, they only last minutes, perhaps hours at most before they burn out. They're typical of ADHD. With bipolar you'd expect at least *some* heightened emotional states lasting 4 to 7 days- which is not what I have

A big part of this is that a lot of psychs have inaccurate stereotypes about who has ADHD/autism & what they look like (hint: its a cis white guy), but also there's a poor understanding of emotional lability. Drs understood I had it, but didn't understand bipolar vs ADHD lability

So "men" mostly don't talk about other emotional symptoms beyond angry outbursts, but "women" are socially conditioned to control their anger, so that anger can slip out in other ways (like my excessive crying). Psychs associate "male" anger w ADHD/A, but not "female" anger

1 in 4 women w ADHD attempt suicide, risk is high in autism too. But when someone perceived as a woman attempts suicide, self harms, seeks help, we get personality & mood diagnoses bc psychs don't associate ADHD/A with emotional lability beyond anger, which women are punished for

So what should be a sign that a person is in significant distress & needs appropriate care, instead becomes a shuffle where low income practitioners spend 10 to 20 minutes with me, slap on a bunch of labels, don't interrogate obvious ADHD/autism symptoms, & play pass the nuisance

Healthcare is for-profit. So is the privately-owned algorithm which determines my "Overdose Risk Score" & thus my worthiness of ~certain meds~. My data points (including sexual assault & CSA, which is only held against women), make me too "high risk" for care- saving Medicare $$

Since I could identify at least some of my emotions (although most only became apparent after learning about emotional dysreg), I knew something wasn't right. I believed in doctors. I sought help. Sometimes I sought help dramatically bc I couldn't articulate it, but I sought help

My cis man partner (who knows I post about him & has given consent), told me that he couldn't really identify his emotions until I started talking about my emotional dysregulation. But as a cis woman, my social norms were different, I was (in theory) free to discuss my emotions

Like most things, it isn't a man problem, it's a "man" problem. A set of gender norms & expectations that any child perceived as a "boy" is held to: boys can't cry (but anger is manly), boys can't talk abt emotion, men certainly can't ask for help, so ofc they don't talk about it

This is, I think, one of the primary reasons so many #ADHDautistic AFABs get misdiagnosed w bipolar or borderline. ADHD & autism often include **serious** emotional dysregulation, regardless of gender. But generally AFABs are willing to talk about emotional lability, AMABs aren't

My partner & I have the same symptoms & had the same crises. The difference is I believed in #Psychiatry, was able to identify/articulate my feelings, & sought help. Thanks to my gender & class I was misdiagnosed, now I have a ~history~. He can get ADHD tx bc he never sought help

@Neuro_Octopus @AutSciPerson But whatever the split is, we always get punished for the 10% of the time we can't control it, while nobody sees or acknowledges the 90% of the time we're chronically stressing ourselves out, exhausted, desperately trying to not get punished for being ourselves. @Neuro_Octopus @AutSciPerson I don't often harm myself outright & accutely, but I had years of eating disorder & chain smoking so I certainly did self-harm to regulate. My 90/10 split largely manifests in severe emotional dysregulation: bottling up 90% of my huge feelings & then EXPLODING when I hit my limit

A lot of these observations didn't hit until I had a child- who I believe is ADHD & autistic like her parents. I'm trying to raise a free, gloriously ND child without trauma. Watching her, I see who I could've been in a world which allows neurodivergent people to be ourselves

My parents were... not great. But they didn't hit me for rocking, or stop me from wrapping my legs as tightly as I could with ace bandages to manage the sensory hell. If they had, maybe I would've developed the 10% self harm tradeoff too (not that self harm necessarily = abuse)

A lot of what is considered ADHD/autistic presentation is really a manifestation of that individual child's trauma based on how the people around the child punish their perceived lack of obedience & respect. How much they are punished for nonconformity & how they learn to hide it

This also helps elucidate why there's so much variability in an individual's ADHD/autism symptoms, even w overarching similarities that unite us. People react differently to us. One parent might beat their kid for flapping, another might force-feed them foods they can't tolerate
My sincerest apologies to new yorkers https://t.co/gIbS36aNGU

@DanielDivergent @AutSciPerson We work & work to avoid displeasing neurotypicals, avoid punishment for being in pain/confused/overwhelmed. But you can only work so much without breaking, & the break is all anyone else sees. We get punished for the break, for trauma spilling out, but never praised for the work

And teasing this out, I never went through ABA, but I imagine a child who has to do all the regular work of masking symptoms without support, *and* has to have the equivalent of a full time job getting trained like a show dog, that's a tremendous amount of work & stress for a kid

Someone who is not in your head may not understand it. You might not understand it yet. Your presentation includes that 10% self-harm, but doesn't include the other 90%, the part that explains how the stress & effort of policing yourself & managing sensory issues is unbearable

If you have severe sensory issues & continually get abused for making your sensory issues known, you might develop a trade-off where 90% of the time you're able to survive sensory hell without making others aware of it, but 10% of the time you hit yourself to release that tension

Our brains are constantly rewiring, adjusting to new information & stimuli, reconfiguring to help us survive our environment. For #ADHDautistic people, so much of our lives are punishment, fear, & trauma, that our brains work overtime to compensate, leaving us stressed & tired

If I could've stood & swayed in class, if I could've rocked without getting actual, literal violence for it from classmates, I probably wouldn't have been in so much trouble for talking & moving all the time. But faced with violence I used dissociation- daydreaming- to manage it

I'm prone to daydreaming, but I was constantly in trouble for being rambunctious as a kid. The more I got in trouble, the more I daydreamed to escape the hell of having to stay still. I have sensory issues that are mitigated by repetitive movement, but I got punished for that too

ADHD & autism are inextricable for me bc I'm both. I don't want to conflate the two, but the "girls are inattentive, boys are hyperactive" ADHD myth really illustrates this well. AFAB kids have less latitude to run, be aggressive, be rambunctious, & it influences our presentation

Sensory issues, emotional lability, hyperactivity, so much of what #ADHDAutistic people experience we get punished for. Over & over again, for decades, we struggle w something emotionally/mentally/physical straining & get punished for it. Our presentation is influenced by trauma https://t.co/yEbuy3uKZj

@DitchlilyB @laurenancona I'm a hot mess in virtually every aspect of life, but my ADHD, autism, & my hyperverbal, mentally hyperactive nature blesses me with these helpful moments of inspiration & clarity sometimes. I wish I could harness it more effectively, but I'm grateful for it regardless

Some ridiculous part of me thinks if I'm smart enough and good enough, if I can magically control my emotional responses & find the words I'm thinking of, if I can be an exceptional dirty poor, then maybe I have a shot at help. But it's never been about me, it's about my class

Healthcare surveillance, algorithms, the way healthcare education, research & practice have been created & maintained (especially in a for-profit system), that's all in service to providing legal drugs & real care to the rich & white while locking out or locking up the rest of us

To me writing a fucking book report about my specific manifestation of ADHD, after over a decade of repeatedly seeking help from doctors, that seems like an awful lot of work if I wanted to "get high." Why would I waste all that time, money, effort when I could just go buy drugs?

Now to my ND ass the solution is clear: compile all the info you can, write everything down, speed read that report to the Dr. But to a Dr, that sounds like a desperate attempt to get ~drugs~ for nefarious purposes. I'm trying to get drugs so I can do my dishes & not melt down

I'm sunk before I start. I don't have a lot of anxiety when I'm home hanging out, but it can get severe when I go to a doctor's office bc that's associated with trauma to me. When they don't ask questions & just throw me another antidepressant it's excruciating emotionally

The knowledge that I have 10mins to communicate the scale of 30 years of MH crisis, poor processing speed & working memory bc ADHD, am poor & marginalized, & know an algorithm often makes the final decision, provokes anxiety which lowers frustration tolerance & increases lability

I try not to get my hopes up, but I daydream about a Dr who cares, & I fall apart when I realize they don't... again. I have 10mins to convince a Dr I am a human being worthy of care before my emotional dysregulation kicks in. A Dr who is poorly reimbursed & primed to distrust me

I'm autistic, I can't stand not knowing *why* things are going wrong, so beyond ruminating on the subject since I was a teen, I also Googled excessively, dxed myself w ADHD & autism, read as much research as I could, & found out about the algorithm that has locked me out of care

There is no fresh start, no second opinion. Instead, there's a legacy of data points & former Dr's notes which paint a picture of us as liars, hypochondriacs, troublemakers, suicide-attempters, & most importantly "drug-seekers," before we've even arrived for our first appointment

In the US, we also have to contend w Bamboo (formerly Appriss, owned by Equifax) healthcare surveillance software, including an algorithm which uses our past crises as untreated #ADHDautistic to generate "Overdose Risk Scores" which determine what treatment we're allowed to have

This emotional dysregulation often includes anger, which to the provider just reaffirms that our "real" problem isn't #ADHDautism emotional lability + medical trauma, it's a mood/personality/behavioral problem necessitating coercion & more of the medications that haven't worked

By the time we're adults we've adopted bad habits just to survive. Our experiences with healthcare have been so consistently traumatic that the slightest push, the slightest indication that we aren't believed or taken seriously, provokes a tidal wave of emotional dysregulation

So we both present differently due to the way our gender is policed, & our "boy" symptoms are misinterpreted based on misinfo, narrow research, & assumptions about how our gender contextualizes our symptoms. Angry girls can't have "boy" ADHD- we must be bipolar or borderline

AFAB kids have a lot less freedom to be loud, boisterous, to goof off, & especially to be angry. Some of us lock ourselves away & escape to a world of daydreams to survive. When our hyperactivity peaks out as swaying, rocking, nail biting, skin picking, it's called "anxiety"

AFABs w #ADHD are often told that we go undiagnosed bc our symptoms are just sooooo subtle & unnoticeable. But I have combined presentation. Many of my symptoms are absolutely typical of "boy" ADHD- including my persistent anger & meltdowns, which was labeled "bipolar" instead

There is a refusal to accept that providers can discriminate against poor people, women, & BIPoC, & hostility at the mere suggestion of systemic bias in mental health research, education, & practice. So anger must become a personal failing- not a response to repeated mistreatment

Some human turd who claimed to work in mental health once told me I was displaying signs of "affective disorder" bc I was ruminating on twitter about the crisis caused by my misdiagnosis & medical abuse. Women are the overwhelming majority of mood & personality disorder diagnoses

The anger we feel, the grief, the sadness, the fury, it's all reduced to noncompliance, "drug-seeking," disobedience, danger & deviance, instead of seen as a natural response to needing help for a long, long time & getting nothing but scorn, lectures, being drugged into oblivion

It's not a coincidence that #ADHDAutistic girls are often misdiagnosed w mood or personality disorders, that Black kids are misdiagnosed with ~dangerous~ alleged conditions like Oppositional Defiant Disorder- quite literally diagnosed with "failure to shut up & take what you get"

Anger is for white cis boys/men. Righteous anger is for white people w wealth. For anyone perceived as a "girl," and/or identifiably not white, anger is a sign of deviant, even dangerous behavior- indicative of our troublemaking noncompliance. We're supposed to shut up & take it

If I had been a boy, I think I would've been diagnosed w ADHD as a young child- like my brother and both male cousins were. But instead, I was just a bad kid. A smart kid, a creative kid, but careless & disobedient, needing "tough love," a firm hand, discipline- abuse & neglect

I've been begging for help most of my life. I remember breaking down screaming & sobbing as young as 8 years old because I was always in trouble, I often didn't understand why, I was singled out & excluded for talking too much & moving too much in school, I was punished at home

If I express any anger, grief, sadness, frustration over this 10+ years of mistreatment, over all the things I've lost? That's always interpreted as anger because I want drugs but some courageous, clever doctor "caught" me & won't be fooled by my tears or manipulations

The moment I got my bipolar misdiagnosis, doctors stopped believing that my back & pelvic pain was legitimate. Suddenly everything became psychosomatic, they stopped running tests & started telling me to try mindfulness, to learn to live with the pain. Misdiagnosis ruined my life

And my long, long history of "drug-seeking" (aka being in a lot of pain from endometriosis, spending a decade begging doctors to do something to try to diagnose me, & crying/raging when they blew me off) is always gonna be more important than just talking to me & treating my ADHD

And it's infuriating that despite my ADHD diagnosis, despite the 5+ hours I spent being tested to make sure I have ADHD, the bullshit bipolar diagnosis that I got within a session or two right after turning 18, is always gonna be treated as the priority, as the "true" diagnosis

ADHD diagnosis is paywalled off, only accessible to people w wealth & private health insurance. An ADHD dx requires hours of testing spread out over multiple appointments, just to ensure you aren't "drug-seeking." But the dx that labels you untouchable? That only takes 15 minutes

I can't even begin to tell you how many poor & marginalized AFAB people I've met w similar stories- they spend maybe 10-15 minutes being evaluated before being diagnosed with bipolar or borderline, & once that happens they are written off as non-compliant, lying, "drug-seekers"

When I figured out my ADHD & autism I thought I was just unlucky, probably because my parents were too poor to afford mental healthcare beyond the low income clinic. Poor & marginalized AFABs seem to be particularly targeted w misdiagnosis, but it's stunning just how common it is

It's infuriating to see how many young AFAB ADHDers, autistic people, & especially #ADHDautistic are casually misdiagnosed w bipolar or borderline the moment we turn 18, heavily drugged w meds that make us feel worse, then spend years or decades fighting for diagnosis/treatment
