A Dr's reputation & ability to work is anchored to their adherence to ideological & economic structures which sway what kind of care they can- or want to- provide. A Dr making bank on expert witness fees in opioid trials is not inclined to keep patients on LTOT, even if effective

Patients & Drs have interests in common, but we have different stakes, relationships to power, & often different goals. A Dr who creates & licenses a new kind of branded CBT for pain mgmt may not have the same goal as a patient who wants the most accessible, effective pain mgmt

Unfortunately there are roadblocks to solidarity between us. Doctors are trained & encouraged to think of patient input as untrustworthy or worthless, they hold the relative position of power. Individually or collectively, doctors are the face of medical trauma for patients

Ultimately, the struggles of healthcare workers & patients alike come down to the systems they must operate within- capitalism, for-profit healthcare, the War on Drugs & DEA stranglehold on healthcare due to CDC's misclassification of illicit fentanyl deaths as Rx opioid deaths

But Drs can only operate within the existing system. A system which thingifies patients, turns them into sources of profit, & only efficiently moves them through the healthcare system if they continue to be a source of profit. Drs adapt to this bc they have to in order to work

Drs are responsible for much of the immediate mistreatment we face, even considering their own relative powerlessness. Drs frequently internalize the discrimination hard-wired into healthcare- dismissing women as "hysterical," thinking BIPoC feel less pain & are "drug-seeking"

Within this hierarchy, patients are at the bottom. If we express any unacceptable sentiment we're dismissed. Often we're dismissed if we aren't the correct gender, race, socioeconomic class. If we're too complex. If our feelings & needs aren't neat, tidy, & easily addressed

Healthcare workers have no say in their work environment, their concerns are not taken seriously. Patients have no say in our healthcare, our concerns are not taken seriously. We're subject to forces outside of our control, frustrated, taking it out on who we can reach: eachother

Within a hospital system, the needs & input of healthcare workers are ignored. They need money, staffing, protection, time to recover. They get pizza & mindfulness. Patients need their symptoms managed. We're told to do self-care, try mindfulness, learn to live with it

Healthcare workers are rightfully angry that nobody in charge bothers to listen to them, when clearly they are the most intimately familiar with what they need. Patients can relate to that feeling- doctors, researchers, politicians, media, they talk to each other, but not to us

Healthcare workers are rightfully frustrated that their pleas for real, substantive help are met with platitudes & empty gestures by the wealthy hospital systems they work for. Patients feel similarly frustrated, ignored, exhausted, & hopeless. We seek help & get platitudes

Over the course of the pandemic, we've seen healthcare workers very publicly (and understandably) rolling their eyes at pizza in the breakroom, when what they really need are the tools to do their jobs correctly & safely- PPE, safety regulations, proper sick leave, & *more money*

Healthcare- both for workers & patients- has been mired in the muck of "wellness," & "self-care," rather than listening to the affected parties & meeting their material needs. Systemic problems have been papered over w platitudes, leading both workers & patients to a crisis point

This is snark, obviously, but it brings up a good point: the catastrophe that healthcare workers are currently experiencing has remarkable similarities to the catastrophe that patients w chronic pain/illness have been facing- especially over the last decade of opioid prohibition https://t.co/RTNtwZzFWa

I often wondered why, as an adult at least, I can do well socially w (some) people my age, why they find me likable, friendly, trustworthy, while doctors find me the opposite. I thought it was me, but it isn't. I'm the same, but doctors expect submission & I can't give them that

The groups of authority figures I clashed with most were/are teachers, pastors, & doctors, all for the same reasons. My emotional regulation is poor, so my frustration at decisions that don't make any sense to me, punishments that seem unevenly applied, is to cry and/or rage

People generally like me, often more than I understand or am comfortable with. But authority figures- with few exceptions- hate me. I question things, I disagree, I get heated when something goes against my beliefs. I hold them accountable & press them to justify their decisions https://t.co/gsj2uow9ug

Autism & ADHD are like Edge & Christian. Both are good singles wrestlers w distinct styles. Christian (ADHD) has a quick, high-flying lucha style, while Edge (autism) is a more methodical brawler w unconventional tactics. Together, they can bring you joy, or they can destroy you https://t.co/uHYMWKfxHZ

What I'm trying to say is that ADHD & autism develop & work in some of the same parts of the brain. When they coexist they can't help but affect each other bc they share training & structure. They can appear separately or together, which affects how they present & are received

If ADHD & autism are a tag team, autism might be pummeling your sensory tolerance until just a touch of ADHD frustration can knock it through a table. Or ADHD disorganization has your unfinished task on the ropes, puts it into a finisher move, & autism comes to complete the move

Before the pandemic I was fairly plugged in w regional indie wrestling. Sometimes wrestlers will work "heel" (bad guy) in one promotion, & work "face" (good guy) in another. Their personalities- like our expressions of ADHD &/or autism- are subject to environment & circumstance

ADHD & autism grow up in the same territory, go to the same wrestling school, wrestle for the same regional promotions. They have moves in common, but each has their own style. They can each be solo wrestlers, they can work separately, but they get "over" (popular) well together

on the back of this thread ⬇️, I keep thinking abt ADHD & autism. For a bit after my ADHD dx, while trying to understand autism & figure out if I'm autistic, I thought ADHD & autism should be one spectrum. I no longer think that. I think of them now as a pro-wrestling tag team https://t.co/8AEycXZYd0

For me, a hyperfocus (short term & all-consuming interest) may eventually stick around long enough to become a "special interest" (persistent, longterm interest, sometimes an exclusive interest). Or a former special interest will reappear as periodic, almost nostalgic hyperfocus

Eventually we've spent SO MUCH time & mental energy breaking down one thing or a related set of things that we can develop new & interesting insights, connections others might not think of or be able to articulate. I think it's part of why we're creative, why we're problemsolvers

Even (or especially) if we can't process something immediately when it happens, our brains grab onto the interesting bits or the things we care about & break them down relentlessly. Mental hyperactivity demands chatter, & daydreams, rumination, breaking shit down fills that need

I think daydreams can also be critical processing tools, allowing us to explore cause & effect in a controlled environment, to train ourselves into responding "correctly" even when we haven't fully processed something yet.

Sometimes this sucks, you may get stuck on a particular humiliation, failure, failed relationships, in my case medical trauma- those are frequent areas of fixation. Rumination can be important to figuring out what happened, it's part of processing how [THING] works

I can only speak as ADHD/A, & even ppl w both can have very different expressions of it. But for me, I'm shit at understanding & reacting to new info in the moment. But if I'm interested/it's novel, or if I benefit from it, I can devote years to processing one thing (like ADHD/A)

I could go on connecting pieces of ADHD & autism all day, but I do want to get to the 2nd point. So, we've got a rough sketch of RTP, but I'm also thinking about perhaps the lesser known/acknowledged processing capacity- or maybe deep processing capacity is more appropriate?

Personally, I feel like my hyperactivity is somehow trying to compensate for poor processing speed, like winding me up? Before housework or while ranting on these long threads, I walk back & forth in my dining room. I've been doing it my whole life. I still call it "revving up"

I suspect that RTP is also heavily linked to emotional dysregulation, perhaps in some way our emotional selves can deduce tone, facial expression, failure, shame, & react emotionally before our logical prefrontal cortex can process what is happening & hold the limbic system back?

For inattentive ADHDers, that gap between receiving & processing information allows for diversions- getting lost in thoughts, daydreams, rumination. We're living life with lag. In an MMO or video chat, lag is somewhere between annoying & infuriating. IRL it can be debilitating

I have auditory sensitivity so I dunno, perhaps my auditory RTP issues are part of that? I'm flustered at traffic circles, frustrated at sudden changes in plans, agitated by filling out forms. Poor working memory, sensory issues, pain, restlessness, boredom tend to make it worse

Sometimes my partner will say "I love you" & there's a long awkward silence before the sound is translated in my brain, then I hurriedly say "I love you!" It was a bit of an issue before diagnosis. When presented w new info, my brain takes longer than typical to make sense of it

What does it mean to have poor processing speed? Well, if someone asks me a question, even if I'm listening & able to hear, I often have to ask them to repeat it. Then halfway through them repeating, I'll answer. It takes longer than typical for my brain to turn sound into ideas

I'm ADHD/autistic. In ADHD testing I was found to have poor processing speed via WAIS-IV, which is an IQ test so... there's already some built in issues. But the highest possible score is 160, the lowest is 40. My processing speed was 68, in the "extremely low" category https://t.co/5FGkF9sCzi

One thing that is really interesting to me is what I call "real-time processing" (or processing speed) vs total processing capacity in ADHD/autistic people. So roughly how fast you can process new information vs how well you can understand it if given unlimited time

@jrphirsch Thanks! My autism and untreated ADHD come with a lot of difficulties, but stuff like this- recognizing patterns & making connections between complex systems- comes easily to me. My real-time processing is garbage, but my total processing capacity is something I'm grateful for

We're seeing what happens when patients are paywalled out of healthcare, ignored, neglected, abused, & milked for cash over & over again for procedures & meds that do not help us regain function. The system was built to fail us- now they want to cry abt not having enough workers?

The institutions, researchers, Drs who are supposed to help us treat us as nuisances while building wealth & careers on new therapies to convince us we're not sick, not in pain- we just need an attitude adjustment. They get research grants & expert witness fees while we starve

Disabled & chronically ill people, people with chronic pain (70% of whom are women), we've been swept under the rug for decades. For the last decade in particular, we've faced extreme hostility, neglect, abuse, & price-gouging for even the least effective treatments

This catastrophe has been a long time coming. Discrimination against women/BIPoC/poor ppl is baked into healthcare & medical research/education. Crisis was sped along by attaching health insurance to employment + the crackdown on Rx opioids & subsequent discrediting of patients

If becoming disabled taught me anything, it's that healthcare is a myth. The white & wealthy are believed, get time, resources, actual care so long as the money keeps coming. If you're poor & desperate to keep working, begging for help, you're labeled a "drug-seeker" & dismissed

So maybe you try to find an apartment you can afford on SSI or SSDI (even if you're lucky enough to be approved, the whole monthly payment is far less than market rent almost anywhere), or maybe you start using heroin or meth (something cheap) so you can work enough to survive

If you were working a respectable job before Covid, but now have such severe pain & fatigue you can barely function, can't work, you're on public insurance, you're not getting pain mgmt. If you can get to a Dr at all they will ignore, threaten, & abuse you until you stop trying

If a disabled person is lucky enough to have family or a partner who can financially support them, they might survive the purge. Disabled people without that support are looking at suicide, becoming unhoused, illicit work, and/or turning to drugs just to survive work

There are 2 options- either give sick & disabled people adequate healthcare & financial support, or purge them from the assistance programs they survive on. The government has already chosen the latter. We're facing a disaster of poverty, houselessness, & increased overdose death

Til now, disabled non-workers have been a relatively small portion of working aged ppl- easily replaced by the next abled worker & thus easily relegated to poverty. But now there aren't easy replacements for low wage workers, bc they're getting sick en masse & have no healthcare

Now so many ppl have been disabled by Covid that the *tiny* portion of money reserved for disabled healthcare & social aid isn't enough. Too many people are sick, the value of us dirty poors as a cautionary tale is outweighed by the sheer number of disabled ppl who can't work

The desperate sub-poverty conditions of SSI, SSDI, welfare, SNAP, they aren't meant to help people to get back to work (if possible). They're meant to create a permanent underclass as an example to low wage workers like "better keep working, you don't want to end up like this"

It's tempting to blame doctors, & many doctors do make deliberately cruel or neglectful choices even within the context of for-profit care, many do discriminate, but ultimately our healthcare system, our medical education & research systems, our profit-oriented system is to blame

There's some part of me that hopes that doctors, seeing their colleagues struggle w long covid the same way patients have struggled, will start to see their patients as human beings instead of overdose risk scores & inconveniences who clog up profitability. But I'm not optimistic

There was an article a while back about a respected Dr who developed mysterious, life-destroying symptoms. She went to colleagues, they did the bare minimum, then sent her to psychs & told her it was all in her head. She wondered how many patients she had done the same thing to

Some part of me is almost... hopeful? Bc so many respectable white people- doctors, lawyers, people who are generally seen as credible- have new chronic illness, maybe we'll make progress that can help the rest of us. But realistically, they'll just become untouchable like we are

This has always been reality for poor & marginalized ppl w chronic illness- being told its all in your head, being told "just learn to live with it" while your life evaporates around you. But w long covid there's a critical mass of ppl who can't be entirely discredited & ignored

Thanks in part to the crackdown on prescription opioids, healthcare & research is more focused on discrediting, gaslighting, & dismissing vulnerable patients than they are in treating them. Preexisting healthcare discrimination makes it particularly bad for women/poor ppl/BIPoC

Covid didn't create this disaster, it accelerated it. Made it an issue for rich people who are used to an endless stock of poor workers to generate profit for them. Govt has attempted to help the rich by revoking aid to force workers back, but disability doesn't work like that

maybe it wouldn't be so bad except it's been happening my whole life so there's trauma attached to it. Authority figures assume my infodumping is lying, my tears are manipulation & my anger is due to being "caught" lying & manipulating. Its crushing for a generally sincere person

If I do speak up, the more info I give the more suspiciously I'm treated, doctors make it clear they don't believe me, they bring up drug testing me despite not prescribing anything the requires drug testing, I get angry bc it's really tiring to constantly be treated like this

My last psych couldn't even be bothered to read the report compiled by the psychologist & therapist who diagnosed me w ADHD combined. She asked if I dissociated, I said yes bc daydreaming is a form of dissociation, she told me it couldn't be ADHD bc it doesn't cause dissociation

My idea was to put together detailed descriptions of my symptoms with examples from childhood to now, a current tally of the things my untreated ADHD make difficult for me, then they'd have to believe me, right? But even if they read it (they won't), it'll be dismissed as a scam

I've been screenshotting the last year of tweets about ADHD & autism, with the plan to compile them into a .pdf and send it to a psych like "this is how much my ADHD affects me, this would be a ridiculous amount of effort for a scam when I could just go buy drugs if I wanted to"

This has been happening my whole life. The more I try to be understood, the more teachers, doctors, or bosses assume I'm lying & manipulating. God I wish the tears were a manipulation, because then I could just not do that. It has never, ever helped me, just leads to more trouble

So I just keep trying to give so many details, so much evidence, shovel all my thoughts onto them trying to get them to understand how I'm feeling & what I'm experiencing, which I guess just "confirms" I'm lying, then NT authority figures get hostile, I get frustrated & cry more

The fun thing about having ADHD & autism is that I'm compelled to over-explain, to ramble, to give tons of details in a desperate effort to be understood, neurotypicals take that as lying or trying too hard, so I get frustrated & start crying, which they take as manipulation

I've been hesitant to bring this up in leftist spaces bc being accused of shilling for capitalists is infuriating, & being accused of being "addicted" (and therefore not worth listening to) is hurtful. But we had 100k+ OD deaths last year. The left needs to get our shit together

I've been accused of "drug-seeking" behavior, I've been accused of working for the Sacklers, defending them, being an enemy of the working class bc I advocate for safe supply. But in reality, I'm advocating for myself, for ppl who use drugs- regardless of why- & don't want to die

I've had chronic pain for 15+ yrs. I got my ADHD diagnosis last year. I can't get treatment for either, bc poverty & unmanaged illness led to suicide attempts. The algorithm deems me "high risk." Drs barely look at me. Like millions of other ppl, I'm on my own to manage symptoms

Regardless of what drugs you use or the reasons you have for using, you should have the security of knowing it is regulated, correctly labeled & not adulterated w one or more unknown powerful substances. You should have the info you need to protect yourself. #SafeSupply does that

My family was profoundly harmed by my dad's alcohol use disorder, my dad most of all. But every day millions of ppl have a drink after work- safely, legally, with the security of knowing their drink isn't actually lethal denatured alcohol (which killed 10,000+ during prohibition)

With a safer, legal, regulated drug supply alongside harm prevention strategies like widespread free naloxone, supervised use sites, safe use supplies, & a robust public health campaign that gives straightforward, non-judgmental safer use information, we can keep people alive

The world where a young adult can experiment with drugs & generally not expect to die for it- that doesn't exist anymore. What might have been a single use or short-term recreational use 10 years ago, may instead become your funeral. The poisoned drug supply doesn't discriminate

With regulated, legal opioids you can be 100% sure that the 20mg Oxycodone you're taking- whether medically or recreationally- is exactly 20mg of Oxycodone, instead of an unknown amount of illicit fentanyl. You can be sure the heroin you're getting is heroin, not illicit fentanyl

A safer, regulated, legal supply of drugs will not end SUD, or even OD death. But right now you can be blacklisted from ADHD treatment for being poor/Black/a woman, buy black market Adderall to keep your job, & die because the "adderall" is just filler & illicit fentanyl

The Black Panther Party considered their community programs to be survival programs- "survival pending revolution." The idea being that you can't be part of a revolutionary movement if you're dead. That's how I think of safe supply- keeping people alive so we can fight for better

We can't legislate drug use away, the last decade has made that abundantly clear. Decriminalization is a step forward, but while it may scale back mass incarceration, decrim doesn't address the tsunami of death caused by having no option but the poisoned illicit drug supply

States have won billions of dollars suing manufacturers of Rx opioids. That money isn't going to affected families, it's not gonna go to housing & healthcare to prevent SUD. Some will go to states, a lot will end up in the pockets of an unregulated, for-profit rehab industry

Despite all the lawsuits & bad press, the Sackler family is gonna be fine. The capitalist system is designed to insulate capitalists from consequences. You know who won't be fine? Millions of people who have lost healthcare, or lost their lives or loved ones to illicit fentanyl

I want capitalists to pay for their crimes, but I'm not willing to kill poor and working class people, women, BIPoC, or put them in prison, in order to get my revenge fantasy against one small part of a massive, rancid whole

As a socialist I certainly understand the impulse to expose particularly vile examples of capitalist greed. But the left seems determined to ignore the big picture- the many catastrophic failures of capitalism, drug policy, criminalization- in order to get revenge on The Sacklers

More people are dying bc safer, regulated, legal drugs are inaccessible. People w medical & mental health conditions are being abused, gaslit, & abandoned by Drs who are afraid the DEA will destroy them for prescribing. Some of those patients will turn to illicit drugs or suicide

In the name of preventing OD deaths, the US has enacted policies & laws that *increased* OD deaths, & established a nationwide surveillance infrastructure in which an algorithm owned by Equifax (NarxCare) determines who deserves healthcare (hint: it's not poor people/women/BIPoC)

The Sacklers Bad narrative of what should be referred to as the *overdose crisis* is backed by shoddy data & War on Drugs ideology. The majority of OD deaths are (and have been) polydrug deaths. From 2005-2016, CDC misclassified illicit fentanyl ODs as prescription opioid ODs

I don't give a shit about the Sacklers anymore. I care about keeping people alive. It is *painfully* clear that the crackdown on prescription opioids (enabled by Sacklers Bad-ism) has not saved lives, it has instead pushed people into more dangerous drug use & increased deaths

What happened with the "opioid crisis" is what usually happens- capitalists exploited the misery, poverty, & illness of capitalism for money. But instead of arguing that substance use disorder is a *capitalism* problem, the left seems determined to reduce it to "Sacklers Bad"

People have always used drugs. More people use more drugs when life is so spectacularly miserable that they feel the need to escape from it, when their bodies are so overworked & broken that they can't stand the pain, when they can't afford treatment for trauma or mental illness

I'm frustrated that so much of the left is still fixated on one bad actor within capitalism- effectively boosting efforts by the US govt to use ~The Sacklers~ as a scapegoat to avoid scrutiny over for-profit healthcare, poverty, & the mental & physical devastation of capitalism

Legalize all drugs including heroin. When Rx opioids were available, less people died (38k in 2010 vs 100k in 2020) Chronic pain patients are dying by suicide. People are dying due to an illicit drug supply adulterated with illicitly manufactured fentanyl. Safe supply saves lives https://t.co/BFnDmbpAcs

Every time I see "autistic people don't understand sarcasm" I cringe, bc my use of sarcasm is one of the reasons I never considered that I might be autistic. We have complicated relationships w social expression which are highly dependent on culture, class, individual experiences

So much of my masking is based in sarcasm, jokes, bits, that it can lead to me being a huge asshole bc I misread a moment, or I don't know how to respond so I choose poorly. Like the time my ex went to a funeral & I did a bit about Crossroads by Bone Thugs-N-Harmony in the car

Its easier to parse sarcasm in media bc my brain is already primed to not take these characters at face value, which is my default in the real world. That tendency to take people at face value, to believe people & assume they're being straightforward, gets a lot of us hurt

Sarcasm in media, & sometimes in written word, is easier for me to parse than sarcasm in reality, because it uses exaggeration/music other "I'm kidding" cues, or because the word choice is purposefully fanciful, or just because another character's reaction tells me it's sarcasm

So I can't stop using sarcasm, often to my detriment, but I also struggle to recognize it in the wild & often react literally to it or just kinda nervously laugh until they either laugh or stay mad at me. Autistic people contain multitudes

The media I used to mask & build a version of myself that is mostly acceptable to neurotypicals was dependant on sarcasm. The Simpsons & Gilmore Girls gave me scripts, intonations, even body language & facial expressions, which I practiced over & over again til it was natural

For me, I use sarcasm tooooo much, even when it's not appropriate, & it regularly gets me in trouble. At the same time I usually take spoken sarcasm from others totally literally unless they use the kind of comedic hyperbole I associate with sarcasm in media

Inspired: some autistic people take sarcasm literally, some are able to infer sarcasm from sentence structure/word choice, some use sarcasm, some don't, some have emotional dysregulation (especially if they also have ADHD, which many do). It's like we're whole people or something

Tired: autistic people don't use sarcasm or have emotions

Wired: sometimes autistic people can't stop using sarcasm & reacting hyperemotionally because we learned to mask via television & every goddamn sitcom & movie uses sarcasm and big feelings to cover for dogshit writing

Those of us who remember the early rumblings of the "opioid crisis," & are currently living with the consequences of untreated pain due to the resulting crackdown, are rightfully worried that news stories mentioning prescribed amphetamines & kratom may lead to a crackdown on both

I can't go back in time & save myself. I can't save myself from further harm & trauma in the present. I worry I can't save my daughter- also poor & a girl- from what I've been through. My knowledge gives me an edge, but bias is quite literally coded into the healthcare system

That's why I get so heated about healthcare & ignorant, harmful drug policy. That's why I fixate on it. I'm comfortable betting that millions of lives & families have been destroyed by locking healthcare behind a paywall & using a fucking algorithm to decide who is worthy of help

Some part of me believes if I can tease out all the connections by constantly analyzing them, maybe someday I'll get the help I should've received as a child. But the logical part of me knows that its not an unsolved mystery to anyone else- I'm just a "drug-seeker." Nobody cares.

Rumination is common for people w ADHD &/or autism, so I'm sure my constant thinking & talking about this (aka the thing that marks me as a "drug-seeker") is part of my autism & ADHD. Believe it or not, it's not much fun for me to dedicate so much mental energy to this either

It's injustice & inequity that haunts me. It's the cruelty, apathy, & mistreatment that leads to endless rumination about what could have been. We know that untreated ADHD can be devastating, but the most devastated are poor & marginalized ADHDers who end up dismissed & abandoned

I'm sure plenty of people, even those who follow me on social media or know me in real life, have written me off as a desperate "drug-seeker." That's the only framework we have for ADHD & pain now. I don't apologize for wanting treatment, but it's a small part of a larger whole

I believe my mom has inattentive ADHD (which runs in her family) & my dad had ADHD + autism. If one or both of them had known about these conditions, been diagnosed & treated, I think my brother & I would've struggled less. I look at my kid & worry about the life she'll have now

My mom's branch of the family has been devastated by undiagnosed/untreated ADHD & subsequent poverty. My aunt seemingly didn't get the curse, has a successful career, and that enabled her to secure diagnosis & treatment for her boys. That's the difference ADHD treatment makes

My aunt is a nurse anesthesist. She has excellent insurance & income. Her boys got diagnosed w ADHD as young kids & have been treated w Adderall ever since. Both are straight A students, one just got accepted to a prestigious university. That's the difference ADHD treatment makes

My grandmother has four grandchildren- 3 boys & 1 girl. The 3 boys were all diagnosed w ADHD by the age of 8. I got myself dxed at age 32. My parents couldn't afford mental health treatment. My brother dropped out & went to prison. I dropped out, worked a few years, went on SSDI

ADHD has higher risk of unplanned pregnancy, poverty, substance use disorder, suicide, comorbid mental health conditions, smoking, car crashes, struggles in relationships, education, career. All of which passes the trauma on & makes their kids less likely to be diagnosed& treated

And it's not just individuals. ADHD is a highly heritable condition, it runs in families. One person not getting diagnosed can harm generations. Whole families are devastated by untreated ADHD. Mine was.

It's an endless cycle of struggle, risk, reproach. The more we struggle, the higher our risk, the more likely we'll be reproached, dismissed, accused of lying for drugs. We give up, do whatever we can to survive, which just makes us more "high risk" & less deserving of treatment

Even if we're able to figure out our ADHD on our own, if we can manage to get a diagnosis, our histories during our 30-odd yrs of untreated ADHD make us suspicious. We're assumed to be lying for drugs. We're told we can't have ADHD bc ADHD doesn't wreck lives like that (it does)

People who are poor, unable to work, incarcerated/formerly incarcerated, have a history of substance use disorder, suicide attempts, trauma, severe longterm mental distress- those are the people who need ADHD treatment the most, & are least likely to get it bc we're "high risk"

It's infuriating to read paper after paper about how devastating untreated ADHD can be, to know how it negatively affects relationships, education, career, health, and not be able to get treatment because you are poor, disabled, utterly non-respectable due to untreated ADHD

@Spencetheghost There's one narrow stereotype of ADHD- the hyperactive white middle class adolescent boy. If you're really lucky, a Dr may recognize inattentive type in white middle class girls. Anything outside those stereotypes (inattentive boys, hyperactive girls) gets missed or misdiagnosed

A Swedish study found 40% of incarcerated people w longterm prison sentences met criteria for ADHD. Only 2 out of 30 had been diagnosed before prison. My brother has ADHD, & spent 6 years in prison. That's what happens to poor & marginalized ADHDers
https://t.co/EITV6oRuRh https://t.co/CJwlYu0z7b

The longer ADHDers go without diagnosis & treatment, the worse our outcomes are. This isn't secret hidden knowledge, all the research we have confirms that untreated ADHD can be *devastating* in a person's life. But the more devastated you are, the less likely you'll get help

In an environment where patients must have a spotless record- no history of trauma or drug use, work in a respectable field, no "catastrophizing," nothing that could be considered "high risk" by the algorithm- it is nearly impossible for poor & marginalized ADHDers to get help

Doctors think I'm being hyperbolic, or "catastrophizing" about the impact pain & ADHD have on me. Perhaps that's somewhat true? I feel things intensely, I've always been told that I'm overly sensitive. But nobody ever considers that my intensity is a *symptom* of my ADHD & autism

If you aren't diagnosed early, aren't a middle class (at minimum) white adolescent boy, there's a significant chance you'll end up dropping out of school, in prison, in SUD and/or inpatient mental health treatment, on disability- all of which make effective treatment less likely

It seems like the more ADHD affects your ability to perform neurotypicality (especially if you're poor/BIPoC/a woman) the less likely you are to be diagnosed & treated. There's a survivorship bias- ADHD isn't treated as debilitating bc the ppl who *get treated* aren't debilitated

I didn't consider ADHD, nobody I sought help from considered ADHD, bc that level of distress isn't associated w ADHD. 1 in 4 ADHD women attempt suicide, I think bc we're so unlikely to be diagnosed & effectively treated. Our ADHD is misdiagnosed as depression, bipolar, borderline

The big conflict is that autistic adults & BAPs have different goals. BAPs may want a cure, or to train the autism away. Sometimes even for seemingly noble reasons- resources are low & abuse is rampant. But autistic adults want a world where autistic ppl can exist without abuse

What bad autism parents see as "mild" autism may in fact be an autistic adult who had to grotesquely contort themselves to avoid further punishment. Bad autism parents claim we're speaking over their kids, but really they're upset we're speaking about *our* condition without them

CW: SUICIDE

Survival is a powerful motivator. If you abuse an autistic for being too identifiably autistic they might present in a more pleasing way. They'll be "fine" til they have a meltdown, until they're alone & self-harming, maybe they'll be "fine" until they die by suicide

When autistic adults who have been through ABA or been abused into masking talk about our experiences, bad autism parents dismiss us as having "mild" autism, or worse some grab onto "this autistic person was abused & now they seem like a real person! There's hope for my kid!"

When we talk about "profound" autism, we have to ask "profound for whom?" I'd say my autism has a profound impact on my life, but a non-speaking autistic person may not feel bothered by not speaking. Who does that label serve- us, or allistics who want to train the autism out?

Bad autism parents see autistic adults expressing ourselves & assume we have "mild" autism & our experiences have no bearing on a kid w "profound" autism. That "mild" autism is often the result of allistic abuse. We mask to survive, hiding our trauma to avoid punishment for it

If "therapy" to stop an autistic kid from hitting themselves is denying them attention/comfort/acceptance, restraining/drugging/shocking them & telling them not to do the bad thing, they might stop. They might use drugs, dissociation, or less obvious self harm to cope instead

I've seen parents claim that their autistic kid is fundamentally different bc they hit themselves, but autistic people have all sorts of expressions of self-harm. Some are immediate & obvious, some are delayed & hidden, but they're all unmet need resulting in self-harm

The existence of autistic adults w perspectives on autism sort of interrupts the fantasy that an allistic parent can put their autistic kid through 40 hours of ABA a week & get an allistic kid out of it. I'm proof a kid can be abused into masking, but I'm no less autistic for it

Mild vs severe, high vs low functioning, profound vs not-profound, it all depends on the idea that if you can communicate about autism, you must not have the same kind of autism. So when autistic adults say "ABA is abuse," autism parents can dismiss us as having "mild" autism

I don't have any degrees, I don't have power or recognized expertise. But if there's a non-speaking autistic person who rocks back & forth, no allistic person is going to understand them on the same level I can. That's the value of inclusive spaces & supports for autistic people

The refrain from some autism parents (not this one, to be clear) is that autistic people who can communicate/behave in socially accepted ways aren't autistic in the same way their kids w "profound" autism are. That ppl w "profound" autism must be "protected" by allistic control

I'm not self-sufficient & independent the way someone would expect a "high-functioning" autistic person to be. I can communicate verbally, be funny, stop myself from rocking, dissociate instead of melting down (sometimes), so I'm seemingly not "autistic enough" to need support

Functioning labels, or "profound" vs... non-profound(?) autism, see autistic traits as linear, on an objective scale from good to bad. Non-speaking? Bad. Speaking? Good. Rocking? Bad. Sitting still? Good. But those are all focused on allistic perspectives around us, not our needs

I'm "high-functioning" (ugh) not bc I can function, but bc I can act. I can dissociate. I can have a long, complex debate about US drug policy, but I go home & can't open my mail bc I don't understand what I'm supposed to be doing. I get overwhelmed til I shut down or melt down

I don't have an issue with fragrances, but certain sounds make me feel like I want to tear my skin off. Certain food textures make me instantly nauseous. When I'm tired, plans change, I'm overwhelmed, etc, I have meltdowns. I've learned to dissociate, but that's not great either

In social interactions, I don't think anyone would think I'm autistic. I spent years devouring books, tv, movies, practicing facial expressions & body language. I have a huge bank of fictional characters & their words to draw on. I also melt the fuck down when I'm overwhelmed

This is a great thread abt how "profound autism" as a category dismisses the expertise of autistic adults & leads to less effective support for autistic kids. I want to add that "severe" or "profound" autism also isolates ppl who have high support needs, but are adept at masking https://t.co/2NkeuCgD0n
RT @Kidfears99: “Shadow pricing” is a term created by PhRMA and fed to the public in 2015 by Bloomberg reporter Bob Langreth to deflect res…

I think this is a big part of why poor & marginalized ADHD/Autistic ppl get misdiagnosed. Drs see the ripples in the water, but they never consider the rock that caused them. They see depression, anxiety, self-harm, rocking, whatever, & use a patchwork of dx to account for them

There's a perception that masked autistic ppl have diet autism or something, like it's not "profound" enough to be autism. Multiple afab ppl have told me they got something like "its autism, but its not severe enough to diagnose." We get the fallout but never see the cause of it

ADHD & autistic ppl have to develop all these unconscious & conscious tricks to fit into a neurotypical world. The things we do to feel comfortable, to think, to process, those aren't socially acceptable, so we end up masking, using drugs, and/or isolating to try to survive it

When I force myself not to rock, even when I don't realize I'm doing it, certain things happen. Sensory stuff, frustration tolerance, emotional dysregulation get worse. Hyperactivity makes me feel like a kettle that can't vent steam. I start daydreaming or ruminating to escape it

I'm thinking about how that happens, how a person can develop this instant, unconscious shutoff of a behavior they would do all day every day if alone. The answer comes back to trauma. I was choked on my school bus for rocking in class, I was mocked & yelled at. I internalized it

It blows my mind that I was able to develop the ability to stop rocking & somehow not even think about it. I knew I rocked, it would sometimes slip out in front of others if I were really excited or agitated, but nobody would've thought of it as frequent enough to be remarkable

Even for the first few years of our relationship, my partner did it too. When he started working from home he'd come out, see me rocking & keep asking "what's wrong?" He didn't know I rocked or paced until like 3 years in. I didn't consciously stop myself, it was just automatic

I've always done this, walked back & forth for hours sometimes, just daydreaming, ruminating, processing, whatever. I got in trouble for it a lot as a kid. I was told I was making people anxious, or interrogated about anxiety I wasn't actually feeling. It was marked as different

He didn't do anything wrong, but I'm so used to the "stop being weird" alarm I didn't even think about it. I just stopped & got annoyed at him, like he was stopping me from being comfortable & doing what I need to do. The shutoff was automatic, so I saw the effect & not the cause

My partner is neurodivergent. He has been my sounding board throughout the last 4 years of figuring out my ADHD & autism. I know I wouldn't get the same judgement, mockery, or violence from him that I get in the real world. But it's so deeply ingrained that I stopped anyways

I was walking back & forth in my dining room trying to get my huge, tangled mess of thoughts in order. Then my partner came out, and I suddenly felt annoyed & resentful. I think it was bc the warning light came on in my head, saying "stop being weird someone else is here!"

"Masking" is an accurate term, but its kind of a charming name for something so deeply traumatic, painful, enforced w humiliation & violence. You end up fencing off most parts of yourself, showing only the least offensive bits. You have to isolate to freely be yourself

I'm having that thing where there are so many thoughts bottlenecking in my brain that I can't express it, I can't get there. It's extremely frustrating bc I know there's good stuff in there, but my "thinking out loud til I stumble onto my point" doesn't work on twitter sometimes

Not only was it shit, but it actively prevented me from understanding my own autism bc I didn't fit into these narrow stereotypes. That's not to say these things *can't* be autism, rather that the stereotype reduces a wide range of behaviors & processes down to a caricature

My (obviously bullshit) concept of Autism used to be a young boy who is incapable of empathy, demanding, irrational, inflexible, good at math, does "weird" stuff, monotonous in tone & expression. It was Max from Parenthood, or the bits & pieces I knew from Rain Man. It was shit

For both, the mental picture people have is a white, middle class, adolescent boy. Their idea of what autism & ADHD is is based on how it can present in that demographic. This results in A. Poor understanding of ADHD & autism, & B. A lack of support & treatment for women/BIPoC

It's wild when I think about what my idea of ADHD & autism was before I figured out my own ADHD & autism. What you get from media, society, even doctors, so drastically misrepresents these conditions, & does so in a way that excludes & harms the most vulnerable ADHD/A people

Because of my gender & neurotypical expectations I'm expected to be nurturing & helpful. But if people get upset with me or around me- especially if I've got my own shit going on- sometimes I'll just not be able to speak, or when I do I just come off as cold even tho I do care

My relationships suffer bc sometimes I don't have enough emotional regulation or just... bandwidth? to respond in socially acceptable ways. Since I can mask reasonably well most of the time, when the mask slips it freaks people out, or offends them, or makes them think less of me

That anyone is still entertaining a ban on kratom after the decisive failure of medical drug prohibition over the last decade is a testament to how thoroughly law enforcement, the prison lobby, media, & assorted Drug Warrior politicians/doctors/researchers have poisoned the well

So in a country with prohibitively expensive healthcare & massive systemic inequalities, kratom functions as a reservoir keeping people who have been locked out of (& harmed by) the healthcare system from resorting to self-medication amid a growing overdose/drug poisoning crisis

I don't want to get into another rant about medical surveillance, so I'll just say that the policy & culture shift has coerced Drs to ignore, abuse, & dismiss poor/marginalized patients. Some patients end up leaving the formal healthcare system, which can put them at serious risk

The algorithm that determines ORS is privately-owned & not open to inspection. But we do know it draws from EMS & criminal justice data in a country w massive inequalities, so the algorithm is likely to discriminate against poor & marginalized ppl the same way society does

When it comes to the things kratom users are seeking help with- pain or mood- treatment options largely depend on what your Overdose Risk Score is. Drs know if they prescribe to someone who is considered "high risk" (despite the issues w that designation) they risk their careers

Kratom use (maybe substance use in general) is to some degree a reflection of the level of trust people have in healthcare. Care is prohibitively expensive, discrimination is ubiquitous, & 10yrs of the healthcare system being mandated to become an arm of the DEA hasn't helped

There are costs associated w kratom, but it's substantially less expensive than insurance, prescriptions, etc. Kratom sellers also do not discriminate against poor & marginalized people (unlike, unfortunately, the medical system), so a ban would disproportionately harm them

The portion of people using kratom in the US is (if I recall correctly) small compared to other substances, but it can be a particularly high risk group- some of whom would feel they had no option left but to gamble on illicit kratom or a poisoned illicit drug supply

People who use kratom have usually already tried conventional treatment, whether that's rehab/MAT, being denied pain management or the meds you can access not working, being traumatized while seeking care. "They can get healthcare!" No, they can't, that's why they're doing it

We dodged a bullet here. If kratom were banned internationally, people would die. People would die bc they use it to get through withdrawal from drugs or to manage SUD, or to manage pain, or for depression & anxiety. Without it, all that is left is a poisoned illicit drug supply https://t.co/1xHjmZfqTh

I think when neurotypicals hear "masking" they think it's always a conscious, planned kind of thing? It can be, or you can mentally reinforce it, but sometimes it just happens without thinking bc our excellent pattern recognition is kicking in to keep us safe from neurotypicals

Without guidance & support, I had no way of connecting all these seemingly unrelated weird things I do- rocking, swaying, picking, tapping, vocal stims, bad body feels, melting down to certain sounds. I never asked *why* I sway & rock, I just internalized that rocking led to harm

After I figured out the autism & ADHD I was just stunned that 1. Nobody else figured it out, and 2. That it took me so long to figure out. I don't rock in front of people, but I do still sway when I stand. I've always gotten mild teasing for swaying but I got violence for rocking

Even not consciously thinking about it, the fear & firsthand knowledge that rocking could result in violence kept me from rocking in front of others. I didn't connect my massive discomfort in public w masking, I didn't ask myself why I only rocked at home, I just tried to survive

My partner didn't know I rocked til we moved in together & he began working from home. The first year he was constantly asking if I was ok & I'd get annoyed. Finally I snapped at him & asked "why?" He said "you're rocking a lot." I buried it so deep I didn't think abt it anymore

I'm pretty good at masking. But it's not because I've got "mild" autism- I had the ability bc I'm hyperverbal, took 8 years of acting classes, lean heavily on movie talk, & I'm terrified. Violence, harassment, & institutionalization are how neurotypicals enforce neurotypicality

If I rock back & forth in public (esp if I'm also emotionally dysregulated, self-narrating, &/or in sensory meltdown) someone might call the cops. Some will consider me "crazy" & possibly even dangerous. I may end up dead bc I'm ADHD, autistic & calmed myself in a visibly ND way https://t.co/XmnZhgrdLT

When I was in inpatient the psych or whatever asked me why I wasn't in treatment for mental illness, but I started doing that at 14. I took so many antidepressants, mood stabilizers, etc & nothing improved. Then I started working & couldn't justify dropping hundreds on nothing

The neat thing abt mental healthcare is you realize something is wrong, you seek help, take the meds, keep seeking help, more meds, keep seeking help, more meds, you give up bc it just makes you feel worse. You end up breaking down & someone asks "but why didn't you seek help?!"

There's a body or brain component, certain drugs may ease symptoms that would be difficult to deal w regardless of circumstances. But the larger problem is how certain traits are viewed in neurotypical society- ADHD/A ppl have to hide themselves to work, love, have friends, exist

I think I was in 5th grade the first time a kid got violent w me bc I was rocking & reading out loud instead of in my head. I made myself stop rocking in public & it fucking hurts. Fatigue, sensory issues, executive dysfunction, emotional dysregulation- they all have a cost

Just... what do I even do with that? What can I do with that? How can I be overstimulated *and* understimulated? How can I maintain routine without being devoured by- and I swear this isn't an exaggeration- a *painful* level of boredom and restlessness?

I need structure, schedule, consistency, but if I have that I'm not the one maintaining it, so my urge to flit from New Interesting Thing to New Interesting Thing tears me apart. I melt down, or shut down, or dissociate because there's too much tension between the camps in me

ADHD & autism have a lot of overlap, but having both feels like I'm constantly, eternally at war w myself. I need sounds to be equal, sensations to be muted, I'm so painfully overstimulated- while I also want to simultaneously gorge myself on every bit of stimulation I can find

I used to describe myself as a "type A personality, but broken." Years later it hit me like a fucking truck: I was describing the way my ADHD & autism interact. I'm *desperate* for structure, but always bouncing between interests, so I'm not capable of maintaining it by myself

So I'm not sorry if CPP are rude, if they don't advocate for some narrow vision of acceptable pain management, if they curse & complain. I don't wanna hear about how unpleasant it is for professionals til they're the ones sobbing on the bathroom floor bc they've lost everything

I've always wanted a kid, but I almost decided against it bc I couldn't imagine raising a child in that much pain. When I got pregnant the pain improved dramatically- it was endometriosis. I almost lost this (& my only pain mgmt) bc nobody considered I might be telling the truth

I think that's where the bitterness, anger & suspicion comes from- we are all too aware of what we've lost. We missed out on loved ones, milestones, accomplishments, watched as our community dies by suicide. Our disabled lives don't matter compared to "saving" ableds from SUD

At the heart of it is a question that goes far beyond CBT- should CPP be required to try every possible non-opioid option (regardless of whether they can afford/access it), & lose years or decades of their lives to inadequate pain care, to prove we aren't "drug-seekers?"

The other day a Dr posted an article he wrote abt how CPP who are focused on opioids are harming all CPP bc they aren't fighting for non-opioid options too. Which is confusing bc I can't think of a law that prohibits me from going to PT, or an algorithm to determine access to CBT

Its frustrating when we bring up this history, these concerns & Drs/researchers/politicians dismiss us as being unwilling to try anything else for pain (bc we're "drug-seekers"). The opposite is true- CPP want opioid access bc we *have* tried the alternatives- 10yrs worth of them

It is frustrating, depressing, humiliating, & traumatic to have debilitating daily pain, especially for the duration some of us have experienced. The idea of yet another therapy or class or whatever that we must pay for to prove we aren't just "drug-seekers" is exhausting

That history (& the trauma that comes with it) makes us suspicious, bc it seems certain to lead to Drs saying "this is a safe effective alternative" without including the "works best with medical pain management" bit. So it just becomes another obstacle we'll have to pay for

We've been repeatedly lied to or misinformed about pain care, including misinfo that culminates in being accused of "catastrophizing" (the new "hysteria") & "drug-seeking." We've been told opioids don't work for chronic pain, we've taken "safe" NSAIDs that destroy our GI systems

Patients know nothing has changed policy-wise, despite evidence CDC overcounted Rx opioid deaths from 2005-2016 & the current post-prohibition OD death rate. We've had up to 10+ yrs of alt tx. Far too many have lost homes, careers, education, relationships while waiting for help

Darnell says Empowered Relief/16 week CBT work best in conjunction w medical pain management, as part of a treatment plan not the entirety of it. Which is great, I agree! The thing is, nothing has changed re: opioid access, so these studies will be used to justify standalone CBT

this matches discussions I've seen abt CBT for pain/ADHD. Ppl who benefit from it seem to be men and/or have medication to help manage pain/ADHD. CBT is *part* of their tx. But when your condition isn't managed it's like being thrown in the middle of the ocean & told to swim home

If my pain or ADHD were managed, if it was no longer a crisis, I could see myself benefitting from CBT as a way to reinforce that I'm safe now, people have my back, I have a path forward- now I can work through pain & things I adopted for my survival that don't serve me anymore

I know I can't adequately describe it to someone who hasn't experienced it, but there is significant trauma attached to having pain and/or ADHD, seeking help, & being ignored/dismissed/accused for years (or decades) bc the people you trusted to help you do not believe you

Its tricky- I believe my BPD partner when he says his therapist using CBT methods helped him. I can see the use for trauma or BPD. But for me its a question of what is being treated, & whether CBT is *part* of treatment or whether it is the entirety or the bulk of treatment
There's just something in this NXIVM thing that hits way too close to home, especially bc both the cult and this approach to pain or ADHD management targets women

I was told I'm in pain bc of depression, anxiety, anticipating pain, not reframing pain, victim mentality/variations on the "sick role" theory, that my pain was psychosomatic. If I didn't agree, then I got the insinuation of "drug-seeking." Nobody bothered to pursue diagnosis

I had a Dr who told me that I'm in pain because I anticipate pain, like the thoughts were manifesting the reality. But I only anticipated pain bc for *years* I would think I'd be ok to go somewhere & do something, then a pain flare would blindside me (& inconvenience others)

I try not to use "gaslighting" when "lying" would suffice, but the things that are being said & done to women, poor ppl, BIPoC... I don't know how else to describe it but gaslighting? And it absolutely wrecks your sense of self, your perception of reality. It's ongoing trauma

I had a vaginal birth for a baby who was over 8lbs, came out upside down, & got wedged into my pubic bone for 3 hours. Barely two days later a midwife said "do you think maybe this 'pain' is really depression?" I had been elated & joyful despite the pain, but that broke me

But it's troubling to watch this NXIVM doc bc the "EM" sessions have a striking similarity to the ways that women, poor ppl, BIPoC are manipulated & pressured to "confess" to exaggerating/fabricating pain or ADHD for drugs or attention, told it's psychosomatic & we need therapy

again it's hard to know if this is something inherent to CBT or if this is an abuse of a useful, valid therapy by inexperienced or unscrupulous providers & providers who fundamentally do not believe women. "Catastrophizing" is "hysteria" w a new name- women still get the label

I don't think it's an accident CBT for pain became popular post opioid crackdown- 70% of chronic pain patients are women. I don't think it's an accident CBT for ADHD became popular during the same time that massively underdiagnosed millenial women began getting diagnosed w ADHD

This gets into the concept of "catastrophizing," the idea that your pain or ADHD or whatever isn't real, it isn't as unbearable as you claim, you're overreacting to it, using it to get attention or drugs, & w therapy you can retrain your brain to be chill again. It's disturbing

I don't know if this is CBT itself, or if it's just the explosion of CBT with inexperienced and/or abusive providers? I can see how CBT can have uses for some people, but now there's CBT for everything & sometimes it seems to function as gaslighting ppl who don't get believed

Especially for things like chronic pain or ADHD, CBT seems to say "ignore all these structural issues, ignore the systemic & institutional forces that have failed or harmed you, you're responsible for your own happiness, you need to reframe your experiences & stop being a victim"

Ok I've never been through CBT, but I know people who have & have discussed it at length... honestly it doesn't seem terribly different from the "ESP" thing in NXIVM, at least in the way it seems to often be used & the impact it has on people
